title: The Staying Power of Leveraged Buyouts
author: Steven N. Kaplan
outcome: Probability of returning to public ownership
context: This study examines 183 large leveraged buyouts (LBOs) completed in the United States between 1979 and 1986, tracking their organizational status through August 1990. The unit of analysis is the buyout firm (and its assets), including both public-company and divisional buyouts valued over $100 million. The institutional setting is 1980s U.S. corporate finance, characterized by very high post-buyout leverage, concentrated manager/sponsor equity, and active LBO sponsors; the paper assesses timing and correlates of returns to public ownership and post-buyout capital structure.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
This study examines 183 large leveraged buyouts (LBOs) completed in the United States between 1979 and 1986, tracking their organizational status through August 1990. The unit of analysis is the buyout firm (and its assets), including both public-company and divisional buyouts valued over $100 million. The institutional setting is 1980s U.S. corporate finance, characterized by very high post-buyout leverage, concentrated manager/sponsor equity, and active LBO sponsors; the paper assesses timing and correlates of returns to public ownership and post-buyout capital structure.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Divisional LBO (vs public company LBO)
Outcome: Probability of returning to public ownership

- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: What Moves the Stock and Bond Markets? A Variance Decomposition for Long-Term Asset Returns
author: John Y. Campbell, John Ammer
context: Using monthly U.S. data from the postwar period (1952:1–1987:2), this paper analyzes aggregate asset returns—value‑weighted NYSE/AMEX stock index returns and 10‑year Treasury zero‑coupon bond yields—at the market level. The institutional setting is the U.S. macrofinancial environment (inflation, short‑ and long‑term nominal interest rates, and changes in Fed operating procedures, notably post‑1979). The authors use CPI deflation and McCulloch zero‑coupon yields to decompose unexpected returns into news about future dividends, inflation, real rates, and excess returns, with subsample analyses (e.g., pre/post‑1973 and pre/post‑1979).
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: How Much Do Taxes Discourage Incorporation.
author: Jeffrey K. MacKie-Mason, Roger H. Gordon
outcome: Fraction of activity in S corporations
context: Using U.S. IRS Statistics of Income data, this analysis examines 1965–1986 industry–year aggregates (seven SIC 1‑digit industries) to assess how liberalizations of S‑corporation eligibility and related tax‑rule changes shifted the allocation of assets and taxable gains/losses across C, S, partnership and sole‑proprietor forms. It exploits cross‑industry and time‑series policy variation (policy‑year dummies for S‑rule changes) to estimate effects on the fraction of activity in S corporations.

title: Do Institutional Investors Destabilize Stock Prices? Evidence on Herding and Feedback Trading
author: Josef Lakonishok, Andrei Shleifer, Robert W. Vishny
context: This empirical study analyzes quarterly end-of-quarter holdings of 769 U.S. all-equity pension funds (aggregated to 341 money managers) from 1985:Q1 through 1989:Q4 across NYSE, AMEX and OTC equities. Using SEI portfolio data ($124bn under management at end-1989), it examines stock-quarter level institutional buys/sells to measure herding and positive-feedback (trend-chasing) behavior, compares patterns across firm size and past performance, and relates institutional excess demand to contemporaneous size-adjusted abnormal returns to assess price destabilization.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Do Bulls and Bears Move Across Borders? International Transmission of Stock Returns and Volatility as the World Turns
author: Wen-Ling Lin, Robert F. Engle, Takatoshi Ito
context: This triplet concerns intraday transmission from New York daytime S&P 500 returns to Tokyo overnight Nikkei 225 opening returns using intraday index data for September 1985–December 1989 (pre/around/post Oct 1987 Crash). Market-level daytime (open-to-close) and overnight (close-to-open) returns are measured with 10:00am openings to mitigate stale-quote bias. The paper finds a generally positive contemporaneous impact of New York daytime returns on Tokyo overnight returns over the full sample, but reports that this contemporaneous effect was not significant after the October 1987 Crash (with a separate lagged NY→Tokyo spillover appearing post‑Crash).
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; event studies; others

title: Peso Problems and Heterogeneous Trading: Evidence From Excess Returns in Foreign Exchange and Euromarkets
author: Martin D. Evans, Karen K. Lewis
context: This paper empirically examines whether excess returns on forward contracts contain permanent (unit-root) components using monthly spot and one-month forward exchange rates and short-term deposit yields for the U.S., U.K., Germany, and Japan over roughly 1975–1989. Units are currency exchange rates and Eurocurrency deposit forward contracts (data from Citicorp and Harris Bank). The authors estimate cointegrating relationships between spot and forward rates and decompose excess returns into permanent and transitory components to distinguish risk-premia from forecast-error or "peso"/noise-trader explanations.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Global Financial Markets and the Risk Premium on U.S. Equity
author: K.C. Chan, G. Andrew Karolyi, Rene M. Stulz
context: This paper empirically examines daily excess returns on the U.S. market (S&P 500) and foreign equity indices—Japan's Nikkei 225 and Morgan Stanley Japan and EAFE—over 1978–1989 (1980–1989 for some indices) to test whether global market integration determines the U.S. equity risk premium. Using market-capitalization weights from Morgan Stanley, the authors model index-level daily returns under ICAPM/CAPM assumptions, account for non-synchronous trading and exchange-rate conversion, and estimate bivariate GARCH-in-mean dynamics relating conditional covariances/variances to expected excess returns.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Global Financial Markets and the Risk Premium on U.S. Equity
author: K.C. Chan, G. Andrew Karolyi, Rene M. Stulz
context: This paper empirically examines daily excess returns on the U.S. market (S&P 500) and foreign equity indices—Japan's Nikkei 225 and Morgan Stanley Japan and EAFE—over 1978–1989 (1980–1989 for some indices) to test whether global market integration determines the U.S. equity risk premium. Using market-capitalization weights from Morgan Stanley, the authors model index-level daily returns under ICAPM/CAPM assumptions, account for non-synchronous trading and exchange-rate conversion, and estimate bivariate GARCH-in-mean dynamics relating conditional covariances/variances to expected excess returns.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Contrarian Investment, Extrapolation, and Risk
author: Josef Lakonishok, Robert W. Vishny, Andrei Shleifer
context: This empirical study analyzes U.S. common stocks (NYSE and AMEX) from April 1963–April 1990, forming annual portfolios beginning in April 1968 and following firms up to five years using CRSP and COMPUSTAT data. Units of observation are individual firms and equally‑weighted portfolios (with checks on largest 50%/20%). The paper tests whether value (low price‑to‑fundamentals and low past growth) versus glamour stocks’ higher returns reflect investor extrapolation/mispricing or greater fundamental risk, using long‑horizon buy‑and‑hold returns, accounting multiples (CP, EP, BM), and macro/market state comparisons in the U.S. equity market.

title: Jumps and Stochastic Volatility: Exchange Rate Processes Implicit in thePHLX Deutschemark Options
author: David S. Bates
context: Analyzes PHLX-traded Deutschemark option transactions and synchronous $/DM futures (Jan 1984–Jun 1991), using a weekly panel of option trades (morning Wednesdays; ~19,689 transactions) and noon futures quotes from the CME. The paper structurally estimates a stochastic volatility/jump-diffusion pricing model (American options, delivery lags, interest differentials, covered interest parity) to recover option-implied parameters and tests their consistency with the time-series behavior of implied variances and realized futures returns in U.S.–German currency markets.

title: Predictable Risk and Returns in Emerging Markets
author: Campbell R. Harvey
context: This claim refers to minimum-variance portfolio analysis using monthly, value-weighted U.S. dollar equity index returns (dividends reinvested) comparing 18 MSCI developed-country indices against the same plus 18 emerging-market indices over 1986:03–1992:06. title: Conditional Asset Allocation in Emerging Markets
author: Campbell R. Harvey
context: This paper analyzes monthly equity returns for 41 country markets (21 developed, 20 emerging) from 1976–1992 with out-of-sample portfolio evaluation over 1980.12–1992.06. The unit is country-level monthly returns in US dollars. Using 60-month moving windows, the author estimates country-specific predictive time-series regressions with global and local financial predictors (lagged world and country returns, dividend yields, FX, eurodollar rate), constructs average conditional covariances, and tests mean–variance portfolio allocations (no short sales, optional 20% emerging-market cap) to assess whether emerging-market predictability and low correlations enhance global portfolio performance.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Asset Sales, Firm Performance, and the Agency Costs of Managerial Discretion
author: Larry Lang, Annette Poulsen, Rene M. Stulz
context: This paper analyzes 93 significant U.S. corporate asset-sale announcements (drawn from SEC 8-K filings and NEXIS) occurring mainly in 1984–1989 for publicly listed firms on NYSE/AMEX. The unit of observation is the firm/asset-sale transaction; authors combine CRSP, Compustat and contemporaneous news (WSJ, Dow Jones) to measure pre-sale performance, leverage and announcement returns. The institutional setting is U.S. capital markets and 8‑K disclosure rules; the sample excludes bankrupt/defaulting firms and focuses on large sales to study how use of proceeds and agency costs affect stock-price reactions.
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Executive Pay and Performance: Evidence from the U.S. Banking Industry
author: R. Glenn Hubbard, Darius Palia
context: This paper analyzes U.S. commercial banks in the 1980s (roughly 1980–1989/1981–1990) using a panel of 147 publicly traded banks across 36 states and DC. It exploits staggered state-level interstate banking deregulation (changes in state laws permitting out-of-state entry) to study how increased corporate-control market competitiveness affected CEO pay levels, pay structure (equity/options), and turnover. Units of observation are banks and bank CEOs; identification leverages cross-state and over-time variation in regulatory regimes with bank- and CEO-fixed effects and year controls.
identification_methods: DiD; other panel regressions

title: A Nonparametric Approach to Pricing and Hedging Derivative Securities   Via Learning Networks
author: James M. Hutchinson, Andrew W. Lo, Tomaso Poggio
context: This paper develops and evaluates nonparametric “learning network” pricing formulas (RBF, MLP, PPR) using Monte Carlo simulations calibrated to a typical NYSE stock (S0=$50, μ=10%, σ=20%) with two years of daily Black–Scholes option prices and six-month out-of-sample tests, and an empirical application to daily S&P 500 futures options from 1987–1991. Units are option contracts and underlying asset prices; institutional details include CBOE strike-introduction rules and discrete (daily) delta-hedging. The focus is on pricing accuracy and hedging performance in market data and simulated paths.

title: Testing Static Trade-off Against Pecking Order Models of Capital Structure
author: Lakshmi Shyam-Sunder, Stewart C. Myers
context: Analyzes U.S. publicly listed industrial firms (Compustat sample of 157 firms, excluding financials and utilities) over 1971–1989 to compare capital-structure theories. Units are firms observed annually with book debt ratios and detailed flow-of-funds components; most firms are large, typically investment-grade. The paper contrasts a pecking-order financing mechanism (debt issued to cover internal deficits) with static trade-off/target-adjustment models, using firm- and year-level regressions, instruments for anticipated deficits, panel and cross-sectional specifications, and simulation-based robustness checks.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; IV; other time-series regressions; others

title: Multifactor Models Do Not Explain Deviations from the CAPM
author: A. Craig MacKinlay
context: This paper examines U.S. equity returns (monthly July 1963–Dec 1991 and weekly July 1962–Dec 1992) using CRSP portfolios and broad indices (value‑weighted market, size/book‑sorted portfolios, S&P indices, and bond indices). Units are individual stocks and constructed portfolios (e.g., 32 portfolios, 33‑asset sets). The work contrasts CAPM and multifactor (APT/ICAPM) explanations with nonrisk alternatives (data‑snooping, sample selection, bid‑ask/frictions, investor irrationality), combining mean–variance theory, simulations, and empirical tests of pricing‑model intercepts.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

# Sign Definitions

- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
This paper examines U.S. equity returns (monthly July 1963–Dec 1991 and weekly July 1962–Dec 1992) using CRSP portfolios and broad indices (value‑weighted market, size/book‑sorted portfolios, S&P indices, and bond indices). Units are individual stocks and constructed portfolios (e.g., 32 portfolios, 33‑asset sets). The work contrasts CAPM and multifactor (APT/ICAPM) explanations with nonrisk alternatives (data‑snooping, sample selection, bid‑ask/frictions, investor irrationality), combining mean–variance theory, simulations, and empirical tests of pricing‑model intercepts.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Missing risk factors
Outcome: Statistical detectability of CAPM deviations

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Mark-Up Pricing in Mergers and Acquisitions
author: G. William Schwert
context: This empirical study analyzes 1,398 successful takeovers of NYSE- and Amex-listed target firms in the United States during 1975–1991 (main sample 1,173 deals consummated within a year). Using CRSP returns, Dow Jones/Wall Street Journal deal announcements and Comment’s M&A database, it studies pre-bid stock price runups, post-announcement markups, trading volume, and the role of insider trading and legal changes (Insider Trading Sanctions Act 1984, ITSFEA 1988) across deal types (tender offers, auctions, MBOs, cash/equity payments).
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Market Timing Ability and Volatility Implied in Investment Newletters'  Asset Allocation Recommendations
author: John R. Graham, Campbell R. Harvey
context: This paper studies 15,133 monthly asset-allocation recommendations from 237 U.S. investment newsletters (June 1980–Dec 1992). Observations are newsletter–months recommending equity vs. cash, converted into replicable S&P 500/cash portfolios. The authors test whether newsletters exhibit market-timing ability and persistence and whether cross-sectional dispersion of implied forecasts Granger-causes future realized and option-implied volatility and NYSE trading volume. They infer expected returns assuming exponential utility and use GARCH(1,1) volatility forecasts.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Investment Opportunities, Managerial Decisions, and the Security        Issue Decision
author: Kooyul Jung, Yong-Cheol Kim, Rene M. Stulz
treatment: Issuing equity when poor investment opportunities
context: The paper studies U.S. publicly traded firms that announced primary equity or bond offerings during 1977–1984 (excluding utilities and banks). Using Wall Street Journal announcement dates together with CRSP returns, Compustat accounting data and issue registers, the authors analyze firm-level security choice, two-day announcement abnormal returns, and one-year post-issue changes in investment and assets. The analysis evaluates agency costs of managerial discretion versus adverse-selection/pecking-order explanations for financing decisions in the U.S. corporate setting.
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: How Different is Japanese Corporate Finance? An Investigation of the    Information Content of New Security Issues
author: Jun-Koo Kang, Rene M. Stulz
context: This paper examines shareholder wealth effects around 875 domestic new security issues by Tokyo Stock Exchange–listed firms in Japan between January 1, 1985 and May 31, 1991. Using daily stock returns and announcement dates from the Nihon Keizai Shinbun, it analyzes public and private equity, rights offerings, straight, warrant and convertible debt amid 1980s deregulation and the late-1980s “bubble” (Nikkei surge and 1990–91 crash). Institutional features (Keiretsu links, bank financing, eligibility rules, credit ratings) and firm characteristics explain cross-sectional variation in announcement effects.
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Explaining Forward Exchange Bias..Intraday
author: Richard K. Lyons, Andrew K. Rose
context: This paper tests whether zero intraday interest rates alter speculative behavior in the European Monetary System by analyzing intraday FX from March 13, 1979 to October 26, 1992. It examines French‑franc and Italian‑lira spot rates versus the German deutsche mark at intraday (market open to close) frequency using weekday observations. The study exploits EMS fixed‑rate tensions and high 30‑day euro‑currency interest differentials as a proxy for expected devaluation and evaluates how interest‑rate defenses affect intraday exchange‑rate returns.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Trade Credit: Theories and Evidence
author: Mitchell A. Petersen, Raghuram G. Rajan
context: Using the 1988–89 National Survey of Small Business Finance (financial year 1987 with some 1986 comparisons) the paper studies U.S. non-financial, non-farm small firms (N≈3,404, stratified by region, MSA status and size up to 500 employees) across industries. It analyzes cross-sectional relationships between firms’ accounts receivable/payable, credit purchases, and measures of access to institutional finance to infer how suppliers provide trade credit and how firms demand it, exploiting industry proxies and the survey’s firm-level financing, sales, and balance-sheet details.

title: Evidence on the Characteristics of Cross Sectional Variation in Stock Returns
author: Kent Daniel, Sheridan Titman
context: Using U.S. CRSP/Compustat data (primarily July 1963–December 1993, with many tests focused on 1973–1993), the paper analyzes individual common stocks (NYSE/AMEX/NASDAQ) and value‑weighted portfolios to test whether firm characteristics (size and book‑to‑market) or factor loadings (Fama–French Mkt, HML, SMB) drive cross‑sectional returns. title: Earnings and Expected Returns
author: Owen Lamont
context: This paper uses post‑war U.S. aggregate financial data (quarterly S&P Composite Index series from 1947–1994, with robustness checks using annual data 1871–1987) to study how the aggregate dividend payout ratio, dividend yield, and earnings predict future excess returns on stocks and corporate bonds. Analyses account for business‑cycle variables, interest‑rate spreads, inflation, and repurchases, and emphasize institutional episodes like the 1970s high‑inflation period and the 1980s repurchase expansion.

title: Heterogeneous Information Arrivals and Return Volatility Dynamics: Uncovering the Long-Run in High Frequency Returns
author: Torben G. Andersen, Tim Bollerslev
context: This paper analyzes one year (Oct 1, 1992–Sep 29, 1993) of high-frequency intraday five-minute Deutschemark–U.S. dollar exchange-rate returns (74,880 observations) constructed from Reuters interbank quotes. The unit is five-minute return intervals in the global FX interbank market, characterized by strong intraday seasonalities. Combining a theoretical mixture-of-distributions model with empirical spectral and time-series analysis, the authors estimate long-memory (fractional integration) in volatility and identify causal impacts of scheduled macroeconomic announcements (e.g., U.S. Employment, Bundesbank meetings, Durable Goods, Inventories) on volatility.
identification_methods: event studies; other time-series regressions

title: How Costly is Financial (not Economic) Distress? Evidence from Highly Leveraged Transactions that Became Distressed
author: Gregor Andrade, Steven N. Kaplan
context: Analyzes U.S. highly leveraged transactions (HLTs)—primarily management buyouts and leveraged recapitalizations completed in the 1980s (mostly after 1985)—following 31 firms from pre-transaction through financial distress resolution (through Dec 1995). Unit of observation is the firm; data come from SEC filings, CRSP, COMPUSTAT and Value Line industry benchmarks. The institutional setting emphasizes high leverage, junk bonds versus bank debt, and Chapter 11 restructurings, aiming to isolate costs of financial (not economic) distress by comparing firm outcomes to market and industry performance.
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Financial Constraints and Stock Returns
author: Owen Lamont, Christopher Polk, Jesus Saa-Requejo
context: This paper studies US publicly traded firms (NYSE/AMEX/NASDAQ) from July 1968–December 1995, constructing firm-level portfolios sorted annually on financial-constraint measures (net cash flow, KZ index, interest coverage, dividend payout). Units are individual firms and zero-cost factor-mimicking portfolios whose monthly returns are analyzed to test whether financial constraints generate common covariation in stock returns. The setting links corporate-finance characteristics to macro shocks—monetary policy, credit spreads, and leading economic indicators—and examines IPOs and dividend omissions while controlling for size, book-to-market, industry, and exchange.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Option Hedging Using Empirical Pricing Kernels
author: Joshua V. Rosenberg, Robert F. Engle
context: This paper analyzes U.S. S&P500 index option prices and index returns using daily data over 1992–1996 (hedging tests on 839 hedging dates). Units of observation are S&P500 index returns and cross-sections of ATM and OTM option contracts. The authors recover daily empirical pricing kernels from option premia via a flexible risk-neutral density and estimate time-varying objective probabilities using a GARCH components-with-leverage model to simulate one-day-ahead derivative price distributions and evaluate minimum-variance hedges.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others
question:
# Role
You are an expert economist.

# Task
Given a context and a treatment–outcome pair, predict the most likely sign of the causal effect.

# Sign Definitions
- '+': The treatment increases the outcome (positive and statistically significant effect).
- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
This paper analyzes U.S. S&P500 index option prices and index returns using daily data over 1992–1996 (hedging tests on 839 hedging dates). Units of observation are S&P500 index returns and cross-sections of ATM and OTM option contracts. The authors recover daily empirical pricing kernels from option premia via a flexible risk-neutral density and estimate time-varying objective probabilities using a GARCH components-with-leverage model to simulate one-day-ahead derivative price distributions and evaluate minimum-variance hedges.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: LVF delta hedge
Outcome: Portfolio standard deviation

# Output Format

- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"

author: Joshua V. Rosenberg, Robert F. Engle
context: This triplet refers to daily hedging tests (1992–1996, 839 hedging dates) of a written $100 S&P500 out‑of‑the‑money (OTM) put position. Units are S&P500 index returns and cross‑sections of ATM and OTM option contracts; portfolio risk is measured as the one‑day standard deviation of option position price changes (dollars per day). The EPK hedge is evaluated against LVF, Black‑Scholes and other hedging methods.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others
question:
# Role
You are an expert economist.

# Task
Given a context and a treatment–outcome pair, predict the most likely sign of the causal effect.

# Sign Definitions
- '+': The treatment increases the outcome (positive and statistically significant effect).
- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
This triplet refers to daily hedging tests (1992–1996, 839 hedging dates) of a written $100 S&P500 out‑of‑the‑money (OTM) put position. Units are S&P500 index returns and cross‑sections of ATM and OTM option contracts; portfolio risk is measured as the one‑day standard deviation of option position price changes (dollars per day). The EPK hedge is evaluated against LVF, Black‑Scholes and other hedging methods.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: EPK hedging method
Outcome: Portfolio standard deviation

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Option Hedging Using Empirical Pricing Kernels
author: Joshua V. Rosenberg, Robert F. Engle
context: This paper analyzes U.S. S&P500 index option prices and index returns using daily data over 1992–1996 (hedging tests on 839 hedging dates). Units of observation are S&P500 index returns and cross-sections of ATM and OTM option contracts. The authors recover daily empirical pricing kernels from option premia via a flexible risk-neutral density and estimate time-varying objective probabilities using a GARCH components-with-leverage model to simulate one-day-ahead derivative price distributions and evaluate minimum-variance hedges.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others
question:
# Role
You are an expert economist.

Given a context and a treatment–outcome pair, predict the most likely sign of the causal effect.

- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
This paper analyzes U.S. S&P500 index option prices and index returns using daily data over 1992–1996 (hedging tests on 839 hedging dates). Units of observation are S&P500 index returns and cross-sections of ATM and OTM option contracts. The authors recover daily empirical pricing kernels from option premia via a flexible risk-neutral density and estimate time-varying objective probabilities using a GARCH components-with-leverage model to simulate one-day-ahead derivative price distributions and evaluate minimum-variance hedges.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Historical regression hedge
Outcome: Portfolio standard deviation

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: The Dark Side of Internal Capital Markets II: Evidence from Diversified Conglomerates
author: David S. Scharfstein
context: This paper empirically examines capital allocation within U.S. diversified conglomerates using a sample of 165 publicly traded conglomerates in 1979 (divisional observations) and follows outcomes through 1980–1994. It studies manufacturing divisions as units of observation, comparing divisional capital expenditures to stand-alone industry peers using three-digit industry Qs, and links investment distortions to managerial ownership (proxy statements) and FASB/SEC segment reporting rules that made segment data available. The setting is U.S. corporate internal capital markets across varied industries.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Do Foreign Investors Destabilize Stock Markets?  The Korean Experience  in 1997
author: Hyuk Choe, Bong-Chan Kho, Rene M. Stulz
context: This paper examines how foreign investors traded and affected stock prices on the Korean Stock Exchange using transaction-level trades and daily foreign-ownership data from Nov 30, 1996 through Dec 1997 (covering the Oct–Dec 1997 Korean crisis). The units are trades and daily observations for 414 common stocks and investor classes (foreign, Korean individual, Korean institutional). The institutional setting includes KSE trading rules (two sessions, batch auctions), SSB foreign registration and binding foreign-ownership limits that changed in 1997; analyses use intraday (5-minute) and daily event windows.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Dating the Integration of World Equity Markets
author: Geert Bekaert, Campbell R. Harvey, Robin L. Lumsdaine
context: This paper studies capital‑market liberalizations in 20 emerging markets (monthly financial series and some annual indicators through the 1980s–mid‑1990s). Using country‑level time series — equity returns, dividend yields, market‑cap/GDP, trading turnover, net U.S. holdings and credit ratings — the authors date endogenous structural breaks in VARs and examine pre/post changes. The institutional setting comprises staggered policy reforms (ADRs, country funds, foreign‑ownership caps, exchange‑rate and regulatory reforms) associated with opening domestic equity markets to international investors.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other panel regressions

author: Bernard Dumas, Raman Uppal
context: This triplet refers to results from a two-country, one-good general-equilibrium model in which financial markets are complete and frictionless while goods markets are partially segmented via a proportional shipping cost. The unit of analysis is representative investors/countries and aggregate welfare. title: Pairs Trading:  Performance of a Relative Value Arbitrage Rule
author: Evan G. Gatev, William N. Goetzmann, K. Geert Rouwenhorst
context: Using daily U.S. equity data from 1962–1997 (CRSP), the paper studies pairs trading across individual stocks (liquid CRSP-listed firms) to evaluate relative-price arbitrage. title: Hostility in Takeovers:  In the Eyes of the Beholder?
author: G. William Schwert
context: This paper empirically analyzes 2,346 takeover offers for U.S. exchange-listed target firms from 1975–1996. Units are takeover offers and the associated target and bidder firms; outcomes include deal success, auctions, premiums (runup and markup) and accounting performance. Hostility is measured via WSJ/DJNR and SDC classifications, unnegotiated tender offers, and pre-bid 13D/rumor activity. Data sources include CRSP (stock returns), Compustat (accounting), SDC, and press wire services, within the institutional setting of the U.S. corporate control market and evolving antitakeover defenses.

title: Profitability of Momentum Strategies:  An Evaluation of Alternative Explanations
author: Narasimhan Jegadeesh, Sheridan Titman
context: This paper empirically examines momentum profits in the U.S. stock market using NYSE/AMEX equities (excluding NASDAQ and stocks priced below $5) over January 1965–December 1997 (with subperiods 1965–1989 and 1990–1997). The unit of analysis is individual monthly stock returns and equal-weighted decile portfolios formed on 6-month past returns (held six months, overlapping). The study situates tests in a Fama–French factor framework, investigates January seasonality, evaluates behavioral vs cross-sectional/risk explanations, and analyzes post-formation returns up to 60 months, plus bootstrap simulations.

title: Behavioralize This!  International Evidence on Autocorrelation Patterns of Stock Index and Futures Returns
author: Dong-Hyun Ahn, Jacob Boudoukh, Matthew Richardson, Robert F. Whitelaw
context: This paper analyzes daily returns on stock indices and their corresponding futures contracts across 24 contracts in 15 countries, using contract-specific samples spanning primarily 1982–1999 (ending Feb 1999). The unit of observation is daily index and futures returns (with volume, open interest, interest/dividend data). The empirical setting exploits spot–futures no-arbitrage and variation in trading volume and transaction-cost bounds to test whether short-horizon positive autocorrelations arise from market microstructure (nonsynchronous trading, stale/bid–ask prices) or behavioral partial-adjustment models.

title: Explaining the Cross-Section of Stock Returns in Japan: Factors or Characteristics?
author: Kent Daniel, Sheridan Titman, K.C. John Wei
context: The paper studies monthly common-stock returns on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Japan, using firm-level data spanning the 1970s through December 1997 (returns available Jan 1971–Dec 1997; portfolio tests Oct 1975–Dec 1997). title: No Contagion, Only Interdependence:  Measuring Stock Market Co-movements
author: Kristin Forbes, Roberto Rigobon
context: This paper empirically evaluates whether stock‑market contagion occurred around three major shocks—the October 1987 U.S. crash, the 1994 Mexican peso collapse, and the 1997 East Asian crises (notably the October 1997 Hong Kong crash). It uses daily aggregate national stock‑index returns (Datastream) for 28 countries (OECD and emerging markets), compares pre/post shock variance–covariance and correlations, and controls for short‑term interest rates to separate true changes in linkages (contagion) from heightened volatility and interdependence.
identification_methods: event studies; other time-series regressions

title: The Market for Catastrophe Risk:  A Clinical Examination
author: Kenneth A. Froot
context: This paper examines U.S. catastrophe (cat) insurance and reinsurance markets from 1970s–1990s with focus on 1992 (Hurricane Andrew) and 1996–1999 transactions (USAA’s Residential Re and CEA’s 1996 deal). Units are insurers, reinsurance treaties, and special-purpose noteholders; analyses use firm- and industry-level reinsurance contracts and premiums, AIR catastrophe-model outputs, and market outcomes across states (notably Florida and California) and Bermuda-based reinsurers. Institutional background includes regulatory guarantees, reinsurance market structure, cat-bond securitization, and post-event pricing cycles.

title: Bankers on Boards:  Monitoring, Conflicts of Interest, and Lender Liability
author: Randall S. Kroszner, Philip E. Strahan
context: This paper studies large U.S. non-financial firms (Forbes 500) around 1992, using firm-level Compustat/CRSP data and bank-firm loan data (LPC/Dealscan, covering lending from 1987 onward). Units are firms and their boards; key covariates include firm size, stock-return volatility (1988–1991), asset tangibility, and short-term debt. title: The Diversification Discount: Cash Flows vs. Returns
author: Owen Lamont, Christopher Polk
context: This paper examines U.S. publicly traded firms over 1979–1997 using Compustat segment data to compare multi‑segment (diversified) firms with portfolios of matched single‑segment firms (matched by 2/3/4‑digit SIC, excluding financial firms and sales <$20m). Units are firm‑years and matched portfolios; outcomes are market‑book (Q), market‑sales (M), and subsequent total returns (equity plus proxy bond returns). The study uses cross‑sectional and time‑series variation in the U.S. corporate sector to decompose the diversification discount into cash‑flow versus expected‑return components.

title: Investor Protection and Corporate Valuation
author: Rafael La Porta, Florencio Lopez-de-Silanes, Andrei Shleifer, Robert W. Vishny
treatment: Cash flow ownership of controlling shareholder
context: This paper studies how legal protection of minority shareholders and controlling shareholders’ cash-flow ownership affect corporate valuation using a cross-sectional sample of 371 large publicly traded firms from 27 wealthy countries in the late 1990s. It exploits cross-country institutional variation in shareholder rights, disclosure rules, and enforcement regimes; units are firms nested within countries. The authors develop a theoretical model and test it with firm-level regressions relating market valuation (Tobin’s q/market‑to‑book) to investor-protection indices and governance controls.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

title: Do After-Tax Returns Affect Mutual Fund Inflows?
author: Daniel Bergstresser, James Poterba
context: This paper studies U.S. domestic equity mutual funds using fund-year data primarily from 1993–1998 (≈5,866 fund-years), with a smaller 1994–1998 sample for gross inflow/outflow analysis and an institutional-fund subsample. Units are individual mutual funds; data come from Morningstar and SEC filings. The institutional setting is the U.S. personal income tax system: authors construct after-tax (buy-and-hold) returns for hypothetical upper-income investors (assumed dividend/short-term tax 31%, long-term gains 20%, 10% effective accrual tax on unrealized gains) and analyze how after-tax returns and capital-gains overhangs predict fund inflows and redemptions.

- '+': The treatment increases the outcome (positive and statistically significant effect).
- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).

# Context
This paper studies U.S. domestic equity mutual funds using fund-year data primarily from 1993–1998 (≈5,866 fund-years), with a smaller 1994–1998 sample for gross inflow/outflow analysis and an institutional-fund subsample. Units are individual mutual funds; data come from Morningstar and SEC filings. The institutional setting is the U.S. personal income tax system: authors construct after-tax (buy-and-hold) returns for hypothetical upper-income investors (assumed dividend/short-term tax 31%, long-term gains 20%, 10% effective accrual tax on unrealized gains) and analyze how after-tax returns and capital-gains overhangs predict fund inflows and redemptions.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Capital gains overhang
Outcome: Gross inflows and gross outflows

title: Government Ownership of Banks
author: Rafael La Porta, Florencio Lopezde-Silanes, Andrei Shleifer
context: This paper analyzes 92 countries worldwide, using country-level measures of government ownership of the top-10 commercial and development banks (measured in the mid-1990s and pre-privatization circa 1985) and long-run outcomes over 1960–1995 and 1970–1995. author: Francois Degeorge, Dirk Jenter, Alberto Moel, Peter Tufano
context: Analyzes France Télécom's 1997 partial privatization share offers in France, using administrative data on 205,076 eligible current and former employees to study who participated, amounts invested, and plan choices. title: Evaluating and Investing in Equity Mutual Funds
author: Lubos Pastor, Robert F. Stambaugh
outcome: Attainable Sharpe ratio relative to benchmarks
context: This paper empirically evaluates equity mutual fund performance and constructs optimal fund portfolios using US domestic equity mutual‑fund return data (CRSP Survivor‑Bias‑Free), with passive benchmark series from July 1963–December 1998 and fund histories through 1998. Unit of analysis is monthly fund returns (2,609 funds; investment‑universe subset of 505 no‑load funds). It compares alphas defined by CAPM, Fama–French (3‑factor) and Carhart (4‑factor) benchmarks, incorporates non‑benchmark passive assets (momentum, characteristic‑matched spreads, industry portfolios), and uses Bayesian/empirical‑Bayes and GMM estimation to account for parameter uncertainty.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Asset Liquidity and Segment Divestitures
author: Frederik P. Schlingemann, Rene M. Stulz, Ralph A. Walkling
context: This empirical study examines 325 U.S. publicly traded firms (assets > $100m) that first reduced their number of reported industry segments between 1979 and 1994. Using Compustat segment data, SDC M&A transactions, and press searches under the SFAS No.14 segment-reporting regime, the paper analyzes firm- and segment-level outcomes—performance, investment, diversification discounts, and an industry-level asset-liquidity index (two-digit SIC annual transaction value/industry assets)—to explain divestiture versus restructuring decisions. Units of observation are firms and business segments across U.S. industries.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: IPO Market Cycles: Bubbles or Sequential Learning?
author: Michelle Lowry, G. William Schwert
context: This empirical paper analyzes U.S. IPO market cycles using monthly aggregate and firm-level data (Ibbotson–Sindelar–Ritter, SDC, and CRSP), focusing on 1960–1997 for aggregate patterns and 1985–1997 for detailed firm-level analysis. Units are IPOs and issuing firms (monthly IPO counts, filings, withdrawals, registration lengths, and first-day returns). The institutional setting is the U.S. primary equity market and IPO pricing/book-building process, emphasizing underwriter behavior, information revealed during registration/roadshows, and investor sentiment/info spillovers across overlapping registration periods.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Risks for the Long Run: A Potential Resolution of Asset Pricing Puzzles
author: Ravi Bansal, Amir Yaron
context: The paper studies U.S. aggregate asset markets using monthly data from January 1927 to December 1998 (CRSP dividends and value-weighted NYSE returns, and one-month T-bills). The unit of analysis is the aggregate consumption/dividend process and market portfolio in a representative-agent, general-equilibrium setting. The authors assume Epstein–Zin recursive preferences and decompose dividends into persistent trend and cyclical components, modeling growth rates with ARMA(1,1) and time-varying volatility (GARCH(1,1)) to link long-run growth risk to observed equity premia and return volatility.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: The Risk and Return of Venture Capital
author: John H. Cochrane
context: This paper empirically estimates risk and returns to U.S. venture‑capital investments using VentureOne financing‑round data from 1987–June 2000 (concentrated in the 1990s), covering ~16,852 rounds in ~7,765 companies. The unit of observation is financing rounds (and underlying firms); outcomes are IPO, acquisition, failure, or remaining private, with exit valuations from SDC/M&A and other sources. To correct selection bias from observing returns only at exit, the author models log‑normal firm value growth and a logistic IPO hazard and recovers underlying moments via structural maximum‑likelihood and market regressions.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions; others

title: FX Trading and Exchange Rate Dynamics
author: Martin D. D. Evans
context: Analyzes transaction-level DM/USD spot FX trading on the Reuters Dealing 2000-1 interdealer system over May 1–August 31, 1996 (79 trading days). Unit of observation is individual interdealer transactions aggregated to five-minute intervals (transaction prices, buyer/seller-initiated orders, trade intensity) across a global dealer network. Institutional setting emphasizes direct bilateral dealer trading, market opacity (private quotes), and the role of customer orders versus common-knowledge (public) news in driving price dynamics.

title: Culture, Openness, and Finance
author: Rene M. Stulz, Rohan Williamson
context: This paper analyzes cross-country variation in investor protection and financial development using 49 countries (excluding recent socialist states) in the late 20th century. Rights measures are centered on laws circa 1993, enforcement indices are averaged through the 1980s–1995, and financial/openness measures use 1985–1995 averages. The unit of observation is the country; regressions examine how culture proxies (primary religion and language), legal origin (common vs. civil law), income per capita, and measures of trade openness relate to shareholder and creditor rights and their enforcement.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

author: Tuomo Vuolteenaho
context: Using U.S. publicly traded firm-year data from the CRSP–COMPUSTAT intersection (1954–1996), the paper decomposes unexpected annual stock returns into cash-flow and expected-return news. context: Using the long U.S. firm‑year panel (1937–1997, ~192,661 firm‑years) aggregated into 40 value‑weighted BE/ME portfolios and a present‑value/clean‑surplus framework, the paper shows that transitory 15‑year expected profitability (together with persistence) explains roughly 80% of the unconditional cross‑sectional variance in BE/ME, while transitory expected returns explain about 20%.

title: Is Disinflation Good for the Stock Market?

context: This triplet concerns the subset of 25 attempted stabilizations of high inflation (pre-stabilization 12‑month inflation >40%), of which 8 episodes are identified as exchange‑rate‑based stabilizations by Calvo and Végh (1998) and Fischer et al. title: Social Interaction and Stock-Market Participation
author: Harrison Hong, Jeffrey D. Kubik, Jeremy C. Stein
context: This paper combines a one-period theoretical model with empirical analysis of U.S. households using the Health and Retirement Study (primarily Wave 1, 1992, ~7,500 households born 1931–41, with limited checks on a 1998 cohort). title: An Empirical Analysis of Personal Bankruptcy and Delinquency
author: David B. Gross, Nicholas S. Souleles
context: This paper analyzes a monthly panel of individual U.S. credit‑card accounts (accounts open as of June 1995) from several large issuers, followed from 1995:Q3 to 1997:Q2. The unit is the credit‑card account (with linked credit‑bureau variables); outcomes are serious delinquency and bankruptcy. The study situates these accounts amid the 1994–97 rise in personal default during a strong economy, considering changes in credit supply (limits, new accounts) and potential declines in default costs (stigma, legal/information costs) to disentangle risk‑composition versus willingness to default.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: The Effect of Capital Structure When Expected Agency Costs are Extreme
author: Campbell R. Harvey, Karl V. Lins, Andrew H. Roper
context: This paper examines whether monitored debt—particularly internationally‑syndicated term loans (and especially subsequent syndicated term loans)—reduces managerial overinvestment in publicly listed non‑financial firms across 18 emerging‑market countries. It combines ownership structure measures (control vs. cash‑flow rights, measured circa 1995–96), firm accounting data (primarily 1990–1997), and a debt‑issuance record (1980–1997). Effects are strongest for firms with relatively high capital expenditures, reflecting intensive monitoring’s role in mitigating agency problems in pyramid‑ownership settings.

title: Dividend Taxes and Share Prices: Evidence from Real Estate Investment Trusts
author: William M. Gentry, Deen Kemsley, Christopher J. Mayer
context: This empirical study analyzes US equity Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs) from 1992–1999 (393 firm-year observations for 85 firms). It exploits REIT institutional features: exemption from corporate income tax, a requirement to distribute most taxable income as dividends (limited dividend discretion), and transparent analyst NAV appraisals. The authors regress REIT market equity values on market NAV and proxies for inside tax basis (book values) to test whether shareholder-level dividend tax benefits are capitalized into share prices.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Short Sale Constraints and Stock Returns
author: Charles M. Jones, Owen A. Lamont
context: This paper studies U.S. NYSE stocks from 1926–1933 using monthly stock-level data (CRSP) and daily loan rates published in the Wall Street Journal’s centralized NYSE “loan crowd” list. Units are individual stocks (211 ever-listed loan-crowd firms and the broader CRSP universe). The institutional setting features a public, centralized stock-loan market where loan/rebate rates reflect shorting costs; notable regime shifts (October 1930 anti-shorting pressure, March 1932 lending restrictions) affected supply and demand for lendable shares. Analyses link shorting costs and first appearances on the loan list to valuation and subsequent returns.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

The institutional setting features a public, centralized stock-loan market where loan/rebate rates reflect shorting costs; notable regime shifts (October 1930 anti-shorting pressure, March 1932 lending restrictions) affected supply and demand for lendable shares. Analyses link shorting costs and first appearances on the loan list to valuation and subsequent returns.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Cronyism and Capital Controls: Evidence from Malaysia
author: Simon Johnson, Todd Mitton
outcome: Stock price of Mahathir-connected firms without foreign listings
context: Analyzes how the 1997–98 Asian financial crisis and Malaysia’s September 1998 capital controls affected market valuations of 424 Malaysian listed firms. Using Gomez and Jomo’s coding of political ties (Mahathir- and Anwar-connected firms), the paper examines July 1997–August 1998 (crisis) and the September 1998 policy/political shock (capital controls and Anwar’s dismissal), exploiting variation in political connections, Bumiputera status, and prior foreign listings to infer changes in expected subsidies and access to international finance.
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Why are Foreign Firms Listed in the U.S. Worth More?
author: Craig Doidge, G. Andrew Karolyi, Rene M. Stulz
context: Using firm-level Worldscope data primarily for 1997 (with robustness checks to 1995), this paper compares thousands of non‑U.S. firms (from 40 countries) that are listed in U.S. markets (exchange listings, OTC/ADR, Rule 144a) to domestic peers to explain valuation differences (Tobin’s q). The institutional setting emphasizes U.S. SEC disclosure and investor protection versus home‑country investor rights (LLSV), accounting standards, market liquidity and capital‑access differences, and the role of controlling shareholders in extracting private benefits.
identification_methods: others

title: A Multivariate Model of Strategic Asset Allocation
author: John Y. Campbell, Yeung Lewis Chan, Luis M. Viceira
context: This paper analyzes strategic asset allocation in US capital markets using two samples: postwar quarterly data (1952:2–1999:4) and long-run annual data (1890–1998). The unit of observation is asset returns (equities, long-term nominal Treasury bonds, short-term bills) and state variables (short-term nominal and real rates, dividend-price ratio, yield spread); the authors estimate VAR(1) dynamics, calibrate an Epstein–Zin infinite-horizon consumption–portfolio model, and construct hypothetical inflation-indexed bond returns to evaluate long-run portfolio choices.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Biases in the IPO Pricing Process
author: Michelle Lowry, G. William Schwert
context: This paper empirically analyzes U.S. initial public offerings (IPOs) during 1985–1999 (primary analyses focus on 1985–1997). Using firm-level IPOs from SDC/CRSP/EDGAR as units, it studies price updates between preliminary prospectus price ranges and final offer prices and subsequent first-day returns. The institutional setting is the U.S. SEC registration/bookbuilding process, emphasizing registration-period public (market/industry returns) versus private (bookbuilding) information, underwriter quality, listing exchange, and after-market volatility as determinants of IPO pricing biases.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions

title: Private Benefits of Control: An International Comparison
author: Alexander Dyck, Luigi Zingales
outcome: Percentage equity held by non-controlling shareholders
context: Using 412 firm-level control transactions from 1990–2000 across 39 countries, this paper estimates the value of private benefits of control (block-premia) and links those country-level measures to financial development outcomes. Units of observation include transaction-level blocks and firms, with country-level aggregates (ownership concentration, privatization methods, market capitalization/GDP). The institutional background exploits cross-country variation in shareholder legal rights (anti-director index), law enforcement, press diffusion, tax compliance, product-market competition, and privatization regimes to explain and instrument private benefits.
identification_methods: IV; event studies; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Characteristics, Contracts, and Actions: Evidence from Venture Capitalist Analyses
author: Steven N. Kaplan, Per Stromberg
context: This paper analyzes 67 venture-capital-backed financings by 11 U.S. VC partnerships, mostly funded between 1996–1999, across industries (IT/software, biotech, telecom, healthcare, retail). The unit of observation is the portfolio-company financing round, using VC internal investment memoranda, term sheets, contractual documents, and subsequent firm outcomes. The institutional setting is U.S. venture capital contracting—pre- and post-revenue rounds, syndicated and staged financings—linking ex ante VC risk assessments to contract design and expected post-investment monitoring.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Stochastic Discount Factor Bounds with Conditioning Information
author: Wayne E. Ferson, Andrew Siegel
context: This paper evaluates Hansen–Jagannathan stochastic discount factor (SDF) variance bounds using US asset return data and simulations. It analyzes annual real stock and short-term interest returns (1891–1985), quarterly real Treasury-bill returns with per-capita consumption growth (1964Q3–1987Q4), and monthly returns on 25 value-weighted industry portfolios (1963–1994), conditioning on lagged instruments (Treasury-bill yields, dividend yield, lagged returns). Units are asset and portfolio returns; the study also estimates VARs and uses Monte Carlo/bootstrap simulations to assess finite-sample bias and derive bias-corrected bounds.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Who Underreacts to Cash-Flow News? Evidence from Trading between Individuals and Institutions
author: Randolph B. Cohen, Paul A. Gompers, Tuomo Vuolteenaho
context: Using US firm-level data (CRSP–Compustat matched firms combined with SPECTRUM institutional-holdings data), the paper analyzes 1983–1998 (23,501 firm-years) to study how stock prices and institutional vs. individual ownership respond to firm cash-flow news. The unit of observation is the firm (returns, book-to-market, ROE, and fraction institutional ownership), within the US equity market. The analysis rests on a present-value/Campbell decomposition of returns and considers institutional constraints (tracking error, transaction/short-sale costs) as mechanisms.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Confronting Information Asymmetries: Evidence from Real Estate Markets
author: Mark J. Garmaise, Tobias J. Moskowitz

context: This paper studies comovement of US equities by analyzing S&P 500 inclusion and deletion events between 1976 and 2000 (inclusions Sept 22, 1976–Dec 31, 2000; deletions Jan 1, 1979–Dec 31, 2000). title: Risk Reduction in Large Portfolios: Why Imposing the Wrong Constraints Helps
author: Ravi Jagannathan, Tongshu Ma
treatment: Imposing portfolio weight constraints (on factor/shrinkage estimators)
context: This paper examines how imposing portfolio weight constraints (no‑shorts, upper bounds) affects out‑of‑sample risk and estimation error for mean–variance portfolios. title: Trade Credit, Financial Intermediary Development and Industry Growth
author: Raymond Fisman, Inessa Love
context: This study analyzes industry-level growth across 37 industries and 43–44 countries, focusing mainly on the 1980s with robustness checks into the 1970s–1990s. The unit of observation is industry–country pairs and the outcome is real value-added growth. For this triplet the treatment is industry external finance dependence (EXTFIN), constructed from US Compustat as (total assets minus retained earnings)/total assets and aggregated as industry medians; country financial development is proxied by private credit/GDP. The design exploits cross-industry heterogeneity and country institutional differences.

title: Stock Valuation and Learning about Profitability
author: Lubos Pastor, Pietro Veronesi
context: This paper studies valuations and return volatility of U.S. publicly listed firms using annual CRSP/Compustat firm‑year data for 1962–2000. author: Thorsten Beck, Asli Demirguc-Kunt, Ross Levine

context: This paper studies U.S. private equity and venture‑capital funds (limited partnerships) in the late 1990s–early 2000s, using limited partnership agreements and investor lists to examine how sponsors choose contractual illiquidity (transfer restrictions) to screen investors. title: Employee Stock Options, Corporate Taxes and Debt Policy
author: John R. Graham, Mark H. Lang, Douglas A. Shackelford
context: This paper empirically examines how U.S. corporate nonqualified employee stock option deductions affected firms' marginal corporate tax rates and leverage decisions around fiscal year‑end 2000. Using S&P 100 and Nasdaq 100 firms (190 firms observed as of July 17, 2001), the authors simulate taxable income and MTRs (accounting for 1998 two‑year carrybacks and 20‑year carryforwards through 2020) based on option footnote data, stock‑price simulations, and firm financials, and relate post‑option MTRs to capital structure (debt ratios) in cross‑sectional regressions controlling for firm size, profitability, R&D, tangibility and liquidity.

title: Mutual Fund Performance with Learning Across Funds
author: Christopher S. Jones, Jay Shanken
context: This paper studies U.S. active equity mutual funds using monthly CRSP returns (January 1961–June 2001), analyzing a sample of 5,136 domestic equity funds (average life ≈77 months). title: How is Macro News Transmitted to Exchange Rates?
author: Martin D. D. Evans, Richard K. Lyons
context: This paper empirically examines how macroeconomic news affects the DM/USD exchange rate by transmitting through order flow, using tick-by-tick transactions (marketmaker-to-marketmaker trades) and five-minute intervals from the Reuters Dealing 2000-1 system over May–August 1996. Daily and intraday analyses link Reuters Money Market Headline News arrivals (U.S. and German macro news) to signed order flow and price changes, estimating structural GMM models with state-dependent heteroskedasticity to distinguish direct and order-flow-mediated news effects in the major interbank spot DM/USD market.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Portfolio Choice and Health Status
author: Harvey S. Rosen, Stephen Wu
context: The paper uses four waves (1992, 1994, 1996, 1998) of the U.S. Health and Retirement Study, following cohorts born 1931–1941 (primary respondents aged ~51–61 at baseline). The unit of analysis is individuals and married households; the HRS provides detailed financial-asset holdings (checking/savings, CDs/T-bills, bonds, stocks/mutual funds, IRAs/Keoghs) and self-reported health. Working in the U.S. institutional setting where older households hold substantial wealth, the authors exploit panel variation in health while controlling for wealth, income and demographics to study health’s effect on portfolio composition.

title: Efficiency and the Bear: Short Sales and Markets around the World
author: William N. Goetzmann, Ning Zhu, Arturo Bris
context: This paper analyzes 1990–2001 equity market data from 47 countries worldwide, using firm-week and country-year observations (individual stocks and value‑weighted market indices) to study how legal and practical short‑selling restrictions and securities‑lending frictions affect price discovery, return synchronicity (MYY measures and R2), return skewness, volatility, and frequency of extreme negative returns. The empirical setting exploits cross‑country variation and several regulatory changes (e.g., Hong Kong, Sweden, Norway, Malaysia, Thailand) and controls for GDP per capita, industry concentration, governance, and year and country fixed effects.

title: Do Asset Prices Reflect Fundamentals? Freshly Squeezed Evidence from the OJ Market
author: Jacob Boudoukh, Matthew Richardson, YuQing Shen, Robert F. Whitelaw
context: This triplet focuses on the impact of the USDA's mid‑October initial forecast of the upcoming season's U.S. orange production (the first official government forecast), using daily New York Cotton Exchange near‑maturity FCOJ futures returns over September 1967–December 1998. The USDA October forecast is formed conditional on a non‑freeze season; the paper documents that the mid‑October announcement day accounts for over 40% of fall FCOJ futures return variance. The analysis exploits the geographic concentration of U.S. FCOJ supply around Orlando, Florida.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; event studies

title: Do Asset Prices Reflect Fundamentals? Freshly Squeezed Evidence from the OJ Market
author: Jacob Boudoukh, Matthew Richardson, YuQing Shen, Robert F. Whitelaw
context: This triplet is assessed using daily FCOJ near‑maturity returns (New York Cotton Exchange) and classified Wall Street Journal articles over Jan 1, 1984–Nov 11, 1998. The paper leverages the geographic concentration of U.S. FCOJ supply around Orlando and shows that, of 384 WSJ stories, over 40% concerned U.S. production or Brazil; Brazil‑related stories are associated with return volatilities comparable to or greater than weather stories. The broader futures dataset spans Sept 1967–Dec 1998, but the Brazil‑news evidence uses the 1984–1998 WSJ sample.

context: This paper uses U.S. annual per‑capita macro and financial data from 1948–2001 to study aggregate stock‑market valuation and expectations. The authors analyze consumption (nondurables & services), CRSP value‑weighted dividends (and repurchases in robustness), labor income, household wealth and excess stock returns to uncover time‑variation in expected dividend growth and expected excess returns at business‑cycle horizons (1–6 years). The approach relies on consumption‑based present‑value identities, cointegration, and VAR/time‑series forecasting to infer changing expectations in the U.S. aggregate stock market.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Payout Policy in the 21st Century
author: Alon Brav, John R. Graham, Campbell R. Harvey, Roni Michaely
context: This paper (NBER Working Paper No. 9657, April 2003) studies corporate payout policy using a 2002–2003 field survey of 384 CFOs and treasurers plus 23 in-depth interviews of U.S. (and some Canadian) public and private firms—skewed toward large, often billion-dollar firms—collected at financial executive meetings and via FEI outreach. The institutional setting is early-21st-century corporate finance in the United States, examining dividend versus share-repurchase decisions amid prevailing tax rules (and the 2003 dividend-tax proposal), liquidity, agency, and signaling considerations across industries.

title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation of Latent Affine Processes
author: David S. Bates
context: This paper develops a maximum-likelihood, characteristic-function–based filtration for latent affine processes and applies it to 11,076 daily S&P 500 returns (United States) from 1953–1996. Observations are daily index returns; the economic setting is continuous-time stochastic volatility and jump-diffusion models used for asset pricing and option valuation. The study compares parameter and filtration estimates to prior EMM/SNP results, assesses time-varying volatility and jump intensities (including volatility-dependent arrival rates), and validates methods via Monte Carlo simulation.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: A Multinational Perspective on Capital Structure Choice and Internal Capital Markets
author: Mihir A. Desai, C. Fritz Foley, James R. Hines, Jr.
context: This paper uses BEA Benchmark Survey data for 1982, 1989, and 1994 to analyze roughly 30,000 foreign affiliates of about 3,700 U.S. multinational firms operating in over 150 host countries. It examines how host-country corporate tax rates, capital market depth (private credit/GDP), creditor-rights indices, political risk and inflation affect affiliate leverage, interest rates, and the mix of parent-provided versus arm’s-length borrowing. Financials follow U.S. GAAP/FASB 52, enabling within-parent cross-country comparisons to isolate responses to local tax and contracting environments (1982–1994).
identification_methods: other panel regressions; IV

title: Asset Prices and Exchange Rates
author: Anna Pavlova, Roberto Rigobon
context: This paper develops a two-country, two-good general-equilibrium asset-pricing model linking terms of trade, exchange rates, and stock and bond prices, and tests its predictions using daily financial data for the US versus the UK (1988–2002) and Germany (1988–1998). Units are country-level asset prices: stock indices, three-month zero-coupon government bonds, and nominal exchange rates (converted to terms of trade via calibrated consumption shares). Key assumptions include stocks as claims to national output, real bonds, country-specific supply (output) shocks and demand/preference shocks, and identification through heteroskedastic latent-factor estimation.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: What Works in Securities Law?
author: Rafael La Porta, Florencio Lopez-de-Silane, Andrei Shleifer
context: This paper empirically examines how securities laws affect stock market development across 49 countries. Laws governing IPO prospectuses and enforcement in each country (legal rules as of Dec 2000) are coded, and market outcomes use five-year averages (1996–2000) of capitalization, number of listed firms, and IPO activity; country is the unit of observation. The setting contrasts private-enforcement features (disclosure requirements, burden of proof) and public enforcement (regulators’ powers), and exploits legal-origin variation as an instrument to address endogeneity.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Uncovering the Risk-Return Relation in the Stock Market
author: Hui Guo, Robert F. Whitelaw
outcome: Bias in estimated relative risk aversion
context: This paper empirically analyzes the US aggregate equity market using monthly and quarterly data: an implied-volatility sample (S&P100) from Nov 1983–May 1995 and longer realized-variance samples (market value-weighted CRSP) spanning Jan 1959–Dec 2000 and 1952Q3–2002Q3. Units are aggregate market returns and conditional variances; state variables include the consumption-wealth ratio (CAY) and a detrended short-term rate (RREL). Building on Merton’s ICAPM, the authors decompose expected returns into risk and hedge components and estimate a structural GMM system using option-implied volatility and lagged financial predictors.
identification_methods: IV; other time-series regressions; others

title: Banks' Advantage in Hedging Liquidity Risk: Theory and Evidence from the Commercial Paper Market
author: Evan Gatev, Philip E. Strahan
context: The paper examines the US commercial paper market and banking system over 1988–2002 using weekly H.8 banking aggregates and a loan‑level Dealscan sample (1991–2002). It analyzes how spikes in the commercial paper–T‑Bill spread (e.g., events like the 1991 Gulf War, 1998 LTCM/Russia episode, Enron-era shocks) affect bank deposits, asset growth, yields on bank and finance‑company paper, and pricing of commercial‑paper backup lines. Units are weekly banking‑system and bank‑level series and individual loan commitments to large firms; institutional setting involves US banks, CP markets, and the implicit government safety net.

title: The Conditional CAPM does not Explain Asset-Pricing Anamolies
author: Jonathan Lewellen, Stefan Nagel
context: This paper evaluates whether the conditional CAPM can explain cross-sectional return anomalies using U.S. equity data from July 1964–June 2001. The authors form value-weighted portfolios (NYSE and AMEX stocks) capturing size, book-to-market, and 6-month momentum strategies, use the CRSP value-weighted index as the market proxy, and adjust for microstructure (nonsynchronous trading). They estimate short-window CAPM regressions (daily/weekly/monthly) and predictive regressions with macro/business-cycle state variables to study time-varying betas and conditional alphas.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Appearing and Disappearing Dividends: The Link to Catering Incentives
author: Malcolm Baker, Jeffrey Wurgler
context: Analyzes U.S. publicly traded nonfinancial, nonutility firms in Compustat at the firm-year level over 1963–2000, studying the propensity to pay dividends and a market "dividend premium" (value‑weighted log difference in payers’ vs nonpayers’ market‑to‑book). The paper links time-varying investor demand and policy episodes (notably Nixon’s 1971–74 dividend controls) to aggregate and firm-level dividend initiation and omission dynamics in the U.S. equity market.

title: World Markets for Raising New Capital
author: Brian J. Henderson, Narasimhan Jegadeesh, Michael S. Weisbach
context: This paper analyzes global public security issuances by firms from 1990–2001 using SDC new-issues data (equity, nonconvertible debt, convertibles, preferreds) across countries and regions, with focused analyses on G7, the U.S., the U.K., and Eurobond markets. Units are firm-level/new-issue observations aggregated to country-region-months; auxiliary data include market-cap weighted returns, Euromoney openness/risk ratings, GDP, inflation and swap rates. The study evaluates where firms raise capital and whether issuance timing responds to contemporaneous and future equity returns and interest-rate differentials, accounting for market frictions and integration.

title: The Declining Equity Premium: What Role Does Macroeconomic Risk Play?
author: Martin Lettau, Sydney C. Ludvigson, Jessica A. Wachter
context: This paper studies U.S. aggregate asset markets and macroeconomic fundamentals using quarterly postwar data (primarily 1952:Q1–2002:Q4) on per-capita personal consumption expenditures, GDP growth, and CRSP value-weighted dividend-price ratios; it also documents international patterns for ten countries (1970s–1990s). The setting is the “great moderation”—a regime shift to much lower macroeconomic volatility in the early 1990s. Units are aggregate national time series; researchers estimate Markov‑regime switches, structural break tests, and calibrate an Epstein–Zin representative‑agent asset‑pricing model with learning.

title: Entry Regulation as a Barrier to Entrepreneurship
author: Leora Klapper, Luc Laeven, Raghuram Rajan
context: This paper analyzes firm incorporation, entrant size, and incumbent firm productivity across 47 two-digit industries in 21 European countries using firm-level Amadeus data for 1998–1999 (supplemented by Djankov et al. measures of entry costs and U.S. D&B industry entry rates). The units are limited-liability corporations (industry×country averages and firm cohorts by age). The study exploits cross-country variation in bureaucratic costs to register corporations, interacting these with industries’ "natural" propensity to enter, while controlling for financial development, labor rules, and intellectual property protection.

title: Corporate Yield Spreads: Default Risk or Liquidity? New Evidence from the Credit-Default Swap Market
author: Francis A. Longstaff, Sanjay Mithal, Eric Neis
context: This paper studies U.S. corporate bond and five-year credit-default-swap markets using weekly CDS quotes and corporate bond prices for 68 firms (March 2001–Oct 2002; Enron case Dec 2000–Oct 2001). Units are firms and individual bonds. Using Treasury, Refcorp, and swap discount curves and proprietary Citigroup data, the authors fit a reduced-form intensity–liquidity model to jointly price CDS and bonds, decomposing yield spreads into default and nondefault (liquidity/tax) components and relating nondefault variation to bond-specific and market-wide liquidity measures.

title: Investor Sentiment and the Cross-Section of Stock Returns
author: Malcolm Baker, Jeffrey Wurgler
context: This paper analyzes how investor sentiment influenced the cross-section of U.S. stock returns using monthly firm-level data (CRSP-Compustat) for nonfinancial common stocks over 1963–2001. The unit of observation is firm-months; sentiment is proxied by closed-end fund discounts, NYSE turnover, IPO activity, equity issuance share, a dividend premium, and a PCA-based composite, each orthogonalized to macroeconomic variables. The setting is the U.S. equity market across multiple bubbles and recessions, focusing on characteristics (size, age, volatility, profitability, dividends, growth, distress) predicted to be differentially affected by sentiment and arbitrage limits.

title: R-Squared Around the World: New Theory and New Tests
author: Li Jin, Stewart C. Myers
context: This triplet examines, across 43 countries (1990–2001), how a country-level DISCLOSURE score — constructed by averaging responses in the Global Competitiveness Report surveys (1999–2000) on financial disclosure and availability of information (thus effectively time-invariant in the sample) — predicts country-year average stock-market synchronicity (average firm R2). title: Corporate Tax Avoidance and High Powered Incentives
author: Mihir A. Desai, Dhammika Dharmapala
context: This analysis examines US publicly traded firms in 1993–2002 using Compustat and ExecuComp panel data, estimating within-firm (firm fixed effects) panel regressions. For the main full-sample tests of incentive pay effects, the authors use 6,816 firm-year observations on 1,381 firms (6,743 obs on 1,374 with controls), measuring tax sheltering as the residual book–tax gap after accounting for accruals and managerial incentives primarily via the Black–Scholes value of option grants as a share of total compensation. Year dummies and firm-clustered robust standard errors are used.

title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation of Stochastic Volatility Models
author: Yacine Ait-Sahalia, Robert Kimmel
context: This paper develops closed-form maximum-likelihood estimation for continuous-time stochastic-volatility diffusions and applies it to US S&P 500 index option markets. Empirical analyses use daily and weekly S&P 500 index levels and the CBOE VIX (a 30-day at‑the‑money implied‑volatility proxy) from January 2, 1990 to September 30, 2003 to estimate models (Heston, GARCH, lognormal, CEV). Units are daily/weekly market observations; option pricing and implied‑volatility inversion map observed prices into latent volatility for structural parameter identification. Monte Carlo simulations assess small-sample properties.

title: Asset Pricing with Liquidity Risk
author: Viral V. Acharya, Lasse Heje Pedersen
context: The paper studies US equity markets (NYSE and AMEX) over the 1962/1964–1999 period using CRSP (daily returns and dollar volume) and Compustat book-to-market data. Units of observation are individual stocks and value- and equal-weighted portfolios (monthly and daily frequencies), sorted by illiquidity, illiquidity variation, size, and book-to-market. Theoretical background is an overlapping-generations asset-pricing model with time-varying per-share illiquidity costs; empirical work uses Amihud’s ILLIQ, AR models for illiquidity innovations, and portfolio cross-sectional tests of liquidity betas.

title: There is a Risk-Return Tradeoff After All
author: Eric Ghysels, Pedro Santa-Clara, Rossen Valkanov
context: This paper uses US aggregate equity returns (CRSP value-weighted index) at monthly and daily frequencies from January 1928–December 2000 to test Merton’s ICAPM relation between the conditional expected excess market return and conditional variance. title: Global Growth Opportunities and Market Integration
author: Geert Bekaert, Campbell R. Harvey, Christian Lundblad, Stephan Siegel
outcome: Ability to exploit global growth opportunities
context: This paper analyzes a panel of 50 countries (annual December observations broadly covering 1980–2002) using country-level units to test whether industry-weighted global price-earnings (P/E) ratios—combined with country industry weights (market cap or value-added)—predict five-year-ahead real GDP and investment growth. Data sources include Datastream, IFC, UNIDO and IMF. The authors exploit variation across countries and over time in financial openness (capital account, equity market, and banking liberalizations), include country fixed effects, and interact openness measures to assess whether openness enables exploitation of exogenous global growth opportunities.
