title: Private Credit in 129 Countries
author: Simeon Djankov, Caralee McLiesh, Andrei Shleifer
context: This paper studies how legal creditor rights and information-sharing institutions affect private credit across 129 countries using annual country-level data from 1978–2003. The unit of analysis is the country (country-year), the outcome is private credit-to-GDP (IMF), and key treatments are an annual creditor-rights index and the presence/introduction of public and private credit registries. Analyses control for enforcement (days to enforce a contract), GDP, legal origin, and exploit cross-sectional variation, within-country reforms, and panel year effects to assess causal impacts on credit development.

title: Explaining Returns with Cash-Flow Proxies
author: Peter Hecht, Tuomo Vuolteenaho
context: This empirical study analyzes U.S. equity returns using annual aggregate data (primarily 1881–2001, with VAR estimations often through 1998) and firm‑level panel data from CRSP‑Compustat (1954–1998). Units are the aggregate market index (S&P/CRSP value‑weight) and individual publicly traded U.S. firms. Using Campbell‑Shiller log‑linear present‑value identities and VAR decompositions, the paper assesses how cash‑flow proxies (dividend and earnings growth, dividend/earnings yields, term and default spreads) relate to one‑period expected returns, cash‑flow news, and expected‑return news.

title: Volatility in an Era of Reduced Uncertainty: Lessons from Pax Britannica
author: William O. Brown, Richard C. K. Burdekin, Marc D. Weidenmier
context: This study uses monthly British 3% consol prices (end-of-month, Sept 1729–Dec 1959) to analyze changes in bond-market volatility across historical regimes. The unit is monthly consol returns for the UK, with comparisons to French 3% rentes. Key episodes include the Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815), Pax Britannica (1816–1913), the classical gold-standard era (1880–1913), WWI and WWII. The analysis controls for inflation, recessions, a callability premium and applies structural-break tests to link political/institutional stability to reduced financial volatility.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions

title: Optimism and Economic Choice
author: Manju Puri, David Robinson
context: This paper uses individual-level data from the U.S. Survey of Consumer Finances (SCF) waves (mid-1990s–2001) to link respondents' subjective life-expectancy beliefs to economic choices. Units are SCF respondents (individuals/households) across the United States. The authors benchmark self-reported expected age at death against actuarial life tables adjusted for age, sex, race, smoking, and education, and analyze associations with self-employment, hours and retirement plans, remarriage, and portfolio allocation while accounting for SCF multiple-imputation and demographic controls.

title: Liquidity and Expected Returns: Lessons From Emerging Markets

title: Multifrequency News and Stock Returns
author: Laurent E. Calvet, Adlai J. Fisher
context: The paper develops and structurally estimates a multifrequency regime‑switching equilibrium model using daily U.S. excess equity returns (a Schwert/CRSP value‑weighted splice) over 1926–2003 (and a 1952–2003 postwar subsample). The unit of observation is the aggregate U.S. stock market (daily index); dividends are modeled with Markov‑switching multifractal volatility and investors have Epstein‑Zin preferences and possibly noisy signals about latent volatility. The setting permits analysis of volatility‑feedback, investor learning, and higher‑moment dynamics in long‑run U.S. equity data.
identification_methods: others

The paper develops and structurally estimates a multifrequency regime‑switching equilibrium model using daily U.S. excess equity returns (a Schwert/CRSP value‑weighted splice) over 1926–2003 (and a 1952–2003 postwar subsample). The unit of observation is the aggregate U.S. stock market (daily index); dividends are modeled with Markov‑switching multifractal volatility and investors have Epstein‑Zin preferences and possibly noisy signals about latent volatility. The setting permits analysis of volatility‑feedback, investor learning, and higher‑moment dynamics in long‑run U.S. equity data.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Higher dividend-news volatility
Outcome: Asset prices

title: Trusting the Stock Market
author: Luigi Guiso, Paola Sapienza, Luigi Zingales

title: Unobserved Actions of Mutual Funds

title: The Myth of Long-Horizon Predictability
author: Jacob Boudoukh, Matthew Richardson, Robert Whitelaw
outcome: OLS coefficient estimates and R2 proportional to horizon
context: Under the null hypothesis of no predictability, the paper shows that in overlapping 1–5 year predictive regressions of annual excess returns on persistent predictors (e.g., AR(1) dividend yields) for the US CRSP value-weighted market (1926–2004), common sampling error across equations produces OLS coefficient estimates and R2s roughly proportional to the horizon; this finding is supported by asymptotic covariance derivations, AR(1) calibrations, and large-scale simulations.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: The Law and Economics of Self-Dealing
author: Simeon Djankov, Rafael LaPorta, Florencio Lopez-de-Silanes, Andrei Shleifer
context: The paper constructs cross-country measures of legal protection against corporate self-dealing based on Lex Mundi law-firm responses about laws in force in May 2003 for 72 countries (covering most global market capitalization). title: Financial Expertise of Directors
author: A. Burak Güner, Ulrike Malmendier, Geoffrey Tate
context: This paper analyzes U.S. publicly traded, large firms (Forbes-listed) from 1988–2001 using firm-year observations (2910 firm-years, 282 firms) to study how directors with financial expertise—especially commercial and investment bankers—affect corporate policies (internal investment, bank lending, M&A, public debt, CEO compensation). The setting is pre-SOX corporate governance; data sources include board proxies, COMPUSTAT, CRSP, Dealscan, SDC, ExecuComp. The authors exploit time-series variation in board composition and a 1976–85 commercial-banking crisis shock to instrument banker-director supply.

title: Securitization and the Declining Impact of Bank Finance on Loan Supply: Evidence from Mortgage Acceptance Rates
author: Elena Loutskina, Philip E. Strahan
treatment: Increasing depth of mortgage secondary market
outcome: Impact of local funding shocks on credit supply
context: This empirical study analyzes U.S. mortgage applications merged with bank Call Report data from 1992–2003. The units are individual mortgage applications and bank-year observations in the U.S. residential mortgage market, where GSEs (Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac) purchase only non-jumbo loans, creating a discrete, annually indexed jumbo-loan cutoff that sharply reduces liquidity. The paper examines how banks’ funding costs, balance-sheet liquidity, and broader securitization depth affect acceptance rates for jumbo versus non-jumbo mortgages.

title: The Expected Value Premium
author: Long Chen, Ralitsa Petkova, Lu Zhang
context: This paper studies U.S. equity markets from 1941–2002 (with robustness checks for 1963–2002 and 1980–2002) using CRSP/Compustat and Moody’s data. The unit of observation is annually rebalanced, value-weighted stock portfolios sorted by book-to-market (quintiles and 2×3 size×B/M). It decomposes the ex-ante value (HML) premium into expected dividend-to-price and long-run dividend-growth components via Gordon-growth based predictive regressions, event-time analyses of firm payouts, VARs with macro indicators (consumption, investment, default spread), and checks including share repurchases.

title: Redistribution by Insurance Market Regulation: Analyzing a Ban on Gender-Based Retirement Annuities
author: Amy Finkelstein, James Poterba, Casey Rothschild
context: This paper analyzes the U.K. retirement annuity market using individual-level data on compulsory single-life annuity purchases (age 65) from a large insurer between 1981–1998 (12,160 annuitants). The institutional setting mandates annuitization of defined-contribution pension balances; insurers price primarily by age and gender and offer a menu of contract profiles. The authors jointly estimate a two-type Gompertz mortality-mixture model, calibrate a lifecycle utility/contract model that allows unobservable saving, and simulate the distributional and efficiency effects of banning gender-based (unisex) annuity pricing.

title: Why do firms hold so much cash? A tax-based explanation
author: C. Fritz Foley, Jay C. Hartzell, Sheridan Titman, Garry Twite
context: This paper studies U.S. multinational corporations using Compustat panel data from 1982–2004 and detailed BEA affiliate benchmark data (1982, 1989, 1994, 1999). The units are U.S. parent firms and their foreign affiliates. The institutional setting is the U.S. worldwide tax system—allowing deferral of U.S. tax on incorporated foreign earnings (with Subpart F and marginal/statutory rate considerations)—so repatriation tax burdens vary with host-country tax rates. The authors exploit cross-firm and within-firm (affiliate) variation to link repatriation tax costs to consolidated, domestic, and foreign cash holdings.

title: What Do Independent Directors Know? Evidence from Their Trading
author: Enrichetta Ravina, Paola Sapienza
context: The study analyzes reported open-market trades by corporate officers, independent directors, and large outside blockholders in U.S. publicly traded firms between 1986 and 2003 (with committee data 1996–2003 and a restatement subsample 1997–2002). title: Information Cascades: Evidence from An Experiment with Financial Market Professionals
author: Jonathan E. Alevy, Michael S. Haigh, John List
context: This paper analyzes controlled laboratory experiments (early 2000s) run with 109 subjects—55 market professionals recruited from the Chicago Board of Trade floor and 54 undergraduates at the University of Maryland—who each played 15-round information-cascade games. Sessions varied urn informativeness (symmetric vs asymmetric) and the payoff domain (gains vs losses), with random assignment of choice order and treatments. Round-level individual decisions are used to study how private-signal strength, public-signal quality, and trader experience affect cascade formation and Bayesian updating.
identification_methods: RCT; other panel regressions; others

title: Does Firm Value Move Too Much to be Justified by Subsequent Changes in Cash Flow?
author: Borja Larrain, Motohiro Yogo
context: This empirical paper studies valuation of the U.S. nonfarm, nonfinancial corporate sector using annual Flow of Funds data extended back to 1926 through 2004 and Compustat firm-level aggregates (1971–2004). Units of observation are aggregate corporate assets and firm-level equity/debt cash flows; the institutional setting is the U.S. corporate sector across major macro episodes (Great Depression, postwar, 1980s repurchase wave). title: Do Analysts Herd? An Analysis of Recommendations and Market Reactions
author: Narasimhan Jegadeesh, Woojin Kim
context: This paper studies US sell-side analysts’ stock recommendation revisions and subsequent stock price reactions using IBES and CRSP data from November 1993–December 2005. Observations are analyst-stock-day recommendation revisions (upgrades/downgrades) with at least two other active analysts, focusing on one-level changes. The setting is US equity markets; the model assumes efficient prices incorporate public consensus and revisions. Cross-sectional variation includes analyst experience, brokerage size, and pre-revision dispersion; event windows around revision dates (and earnings) are used to infer market interpretation of herding incentives.
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: The Term Structure of Real Rates and Expected Inflation
author: Andrew Ang, Geert Bekaert, Min Wei
context: Analyzes U.S. quarterly nominal zero-coupon Treasury yields and CPI inflation from 1952:Q2–2004:Q4. The unit of observation is aggregate quarterly financial/macro series (short- and long-maturity yields and CPI inflation). Using a no-arbitrage, regime-switching term structure model with time-varying prices of risk, the paper decomposes nominal yields into real yields, expected inflation, and an inflation risk premium across monetary-regime episodes (e.g., 1979–82 monetary targeting, Volcker disinflation) and addresses identification limits of inflation-indexed bonds.

title: Has New York Become Less Competitive in Global Markets? Evaluating Foreign Listing Choices Over Time
author: Craig Doidge, G. Andrew Karolyi, Rene M. Stulz
context: Using firm-level data on non-U.S. firms from 1990–2005, this triplet concerns firms' post-listing capital raising — measured as security issuances at home, in the U.S., the U.K., and other markets. title: Do Security Analysts Speak in Two Tongues?
author: Ulrike Malmendier, Devin Shanthikumar
context: This empirical study examines U.S. security analysts’ recommendations and annual earnings forecasts using IBES data (primarily 1994–2008) and NYSE TAQ trading data (1993–2002). The units are analyst–stock–day observations and investor trades (small vs. large) for U.S.-listed firms (NYSE, Amex, NASDAQ). The institutional setting emphasizes incentives from underwriter affiliation, investment-banking pressure, reputational capital, and the post-2001 analyst conflicts-of-interest spotlight, exploiting earnings-announcement and recommendation/forecast update windows.

title: Neighbors Matter: Causal Community Effects and Stock Market Participation
author: Jeffrey R. Brown, Zoran Ivkovich, Paul A. Smith, Scott Weisbenner
context: This paper uses a 1987–1996 panel of U.S. federal tax returns (zip-code/MSA identifiers) to estimate whether community stock-market participation causes individual taxable stock ownership. The unit is taxpayers/households in 337 U.S. MSAs, with the core sample restricted to “natives” who remain in the same MSA and birth state. The analysis merges Census, Compustat/CRSP, and DDB sociability data and focuses on equity ownership in taxable accounts, exploiting Social Security birth-state information to build instruments for neighbor ownership while controlling for rich time-varying and fixed effects.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions

title: Managerial Ownership Dynamics and Firm Value

title: Financial Literacy and Stock Market Participation
author: Maarten van Rooij, Annamaria Lusardi, Rob Alessie
context: Using 2005–2006 modules of the DNB Household Survey, this paper studies Dutch households (respondents aged ~22–90) to assess how financial literacy influences household stock-market participation. It links basic and advanced literacy measures to stock ownership, exploits variation in early-life exposure to economics education (schooling cohorts who attended school before the 1990s stock-market expansion) as an instrument, and leverages institutional context (Euro conversion in 2002, 2005 health‑insurance reform) to address cognition and endogeneity concerns.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions

title: When Does a Mutual Fund's Trade Reveal its Skill?
author: Zhi Da, Pengjie Gao, Ravi Jagannathan
context: This paper studies US active equity mutual funds and the stocks they trade using quarterly holdings and tick-by-tick transactions from 1983–2004. Units are mutual fund-quarter observations and individual stocks (NYSE, AMEX, NASDAQ). The authors infer trades from quarter-end holdings, measure information-events with the probability of informed trading (PIN) and alternative measures, and evaluate fund performance using Carhart four-factor alphas and characteristics-based (DGTW) selectivity, controlling for PIN risk to examine how trading in high-PIN stocks reveals manager skill and persistence.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Mixing Family With Business: A Study of Thai Business Groups and the Families Behind Them
author: Marianne Bertrand, Simon Johnson, Krislert Samphantharak, Antoinette Schoar
outcome: Fraction of ownership held by sons
context: This paper studies nearly 100 of Thailand’s largest family business groups using hand-collected family trees and firm-level ownership, board and financial data for 1996 (pre-1997 Asian crisis). Units of observation are firms and family groups (93 families, several hundred group firms, both public and private). The institutional setting is Thai business groups with pyramidal ownership and weak minority protections; key variation exploits cross-family differences (family size, number of sons) and founder presence (alive vs. dead) to link family structure to governance and firm performance.

title: High Idiosyncratic Volatility and Low Returns: International and Further U.S. Evidence
author: Andrew Ang, Robert J. Hodrick, Yuhang Xing, Xiaoyan Zhang
context: This paper studies the cross-sectional relation between lagged idiosyncratic stock-return volatility and subsequent average returns using firm-level daily and monthly returns from July 1963–December 2003 for the U.S. and January 1980–December 2003 for 23 developed markets (G7 and other developed countries). Units are individual publicly listed firms/stocks; returns and volatility are measured in USD and local currency using local, regional and world Fama–French models. Analyses use monthly portfolio sorts and cross-sectional/time-series regressions controlling for size, value, momentum and trading/information frictions.

title: Big Business Stability and Social Welfare
author: Kathy Fogel, Randall Morck, Bernard Yeung
context: This paper performs a cross-country empirical analysis of big business stability using lists of the ten largest employers in 1975 and their persistence to 1996 for 43 countries. title: Common Risk Factors in Currency Markets
author: Hanno Lustig, Nikolai Roussanov, Adrien Verdelhan
context: This paper analyzes monthly spot and one-month forward exchange rates for 37 developed and emerging currencies from November 1983 to March 2008, from the perspective of a U.S. investor. It forms six portfolios sorted by forward discounts (interest differentials), accounts for bid–ask transaction costs, and links cross-sectional carry-trade returns and time-series predictability to a common global stochastic discount factor. The analysis situates currency risk premia in a no-arbitrage affine asset-pricing framework and relates them to U.S. macrofinancial indicators (industrial production, payrolls, VIX).
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: A Gap-Filling Theory of Corporate Debt Maturity Choice
author: Robin Greenwood, Samuel Hanson, Jeremy C. Stein
context: This paper examines U.S. corporate and Treasury debt maturity from 1963–2005 (with robustness to 1953–2005), using aggregate Flow of Funds, CRSP Treasury records, and Compustat firm-level data. Units include the nonfinancial corporate sector (aggregate issuance and levels) and individual public firms. The institutional setting is the U.S. bond market, where variation in government debt maturity and the debt-to-GDP ratio generate supply shocks; analyses exploit these shifts, yield and credit-spread conditions, and firm balance-sheet heterogeneity to test gap-filling and forecasting effects.

title: Why Do Foreign Firms Leave U.S. Equity Markets?
author: Craig Doidge, G. Andrew Karolyi, René M. Stulz
treatment: Announcements that foreign firms would not be exempt from SOX
context: This paper studies foreign firms’ deregistration from U.S. equity markets between 2002 and 2008, focusing on firms listed on major U.S. exchanges (including ADRs). The unit of analysis is firms and deregistration events; key institutional shocks are the Sarbanes–Oxley Act (SOX) passage in 2002 and the SEC’s Exchange Act Rule 12h-6 (adopted March 21, 2007, effective June 4, 2007) that eased foreign private issuers’ deregistration. The authors compare deregistering firms to other U.S.-listed foreign firms across financial, governance, and stock-return outcomes to test bonding versus loss-of-competitiveness mechanisms.

title: Product Market Synergies and Competition in Mergers and Acquisitions: A Text-Based Analysis
author: Gerard Hoberg, Gordon M. Phillips
context: Using U.S. publicly traded firms’ SEC 10-K product descriptions from fiscal years 1997–2005 merged to COMPUSTAT/CRSP and SDC Platinum, the paper analyzes firm-year and deal-level outcomes (firms, targets, acquirers, and M&A transactions) in the United States. It studies how text-based measures of product similarity and local product-market competition predict (i) firms’ likelihood of being targets or acquirers, (ii) combined announcement returns (event windows up to ten days), and (iii) post-merger real outcomes (profitability, sales growth, product-description growth) over one- to three-year horizons.

title: Post-Merger Restructuring and the Boundaries of the Firm
author: Vojislav Maksimovic, Gordon Phillips, N. R. Prabhala
treatment: Positive industry return shock × high acquirer marginal skill
context: This paper studies U.S. manufacturing mergers completed 1981–2000 (matched to Census LRD plant data through 2004), following acquired plants for three years after acquisition to analyze post-merger restructuring. title: Fooling Some of the People All of the Time: The Inefficient Performance and Persistence of Commodity Trading Advisors
author: Geetesh Bhardwaj, Gary B. Gorton, K. Geert Rouwenhorst
context: Using Lipper-TASS performance data for commodity trading advisors (CTAs) reporting in the U.S. markets, the paper studies CTA performance, fees, and persistence over 1994–2007. The unit of observation is individual CTA funds (and equally-weighted CTA indices); the institutional setting emphasizes voluntary reporting to vendor databases, resulting in backfill, survivorship and look-back biases, and a regulatory/background comparison to earlier publicly-offered commodity pools. Analyses adjust for fees (estimating gross returns) and benchmark CTA returns to public dynamic futures-based strategies.

treatment: Change in fund NAV since purchase
context: This triplet refers to household-level mutual-fund purchases by individual U.S. investors in the brokerage sample (Jan 1991–Nov 1996; ~78,000 households, ~325,000 purchases across ~1,100 funds) and, specifically, holdings in taxable accounts. question:
# Role
You are an expert economist.

# Task
Given a context and a treatment–outcome pair, predict the most likely sign of the causal effect.

# Sign Definitions
- '+': The treatment increases the outcome (positive and statistically significant effect).
- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
This triplet refers to household-level mutual-fund purchases by individual U.S. investors in the brokerage sample (Jan 1991–Nov 1996; ~78,000 households, ~325,000 purchases across ~1,100 funds) and, specifically, holdings in taxable accounts. The outcome is the monthly probability of sale in months since purchase; the treatment is NAV_RETURN (change in fund NAV since purchase, i.e., total returns minus distributions). Estimates come from a Cox proportional-hazards model with nonparametric baseline hazards for each investor–mutual-fund-type (objective × index status × family).

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Change in fund NAV since purchase
Outcome: Probability of sale

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Individual Investor Mutual-Fund Flows
author: Zoran Ivkovich, Scott Weisbenner
context: This paper examines individual U.S. investors’ mutual-fund trading using detailed brokerage transactions for ~78,000 households from January 1991–November 1996 (over 325,000 purchases across ~1,100 funds). Units are household-level fund purchases/sales and monthly fund-level inflows/outflows, with holdings split into taxable and tax-deferred accounts. Fund characteristics come from CRSP and Morningstar. The institutional setting includes U.S. realization-based capital-gains taxation, fund expense ratios and loads, allowing within-investor and within-fund comparisons to identify tax-motivated trading and cost sensitivities.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Private Equity and Long-Run Investment: The Case of Innovation
author: Josh Lerner, Morten Sørensen, Per Strömberg
context: This empirical study examines how private equity (primarily leveraged buyouts) affects firms’ long‑run innovative investment by linking Capital IQ transactions (closed 1980–2005) to U.S. USPTO patent grants observed through May 2007. The units are firms (495 private equity‑backed entities) and their patents (≈6,938 grants); analyses focus on event windows three years before to five years after a transaction. The setting evaluates changes in patent counts, citations, originality, generality, and portfolio concentration using patent‑class/year controls and firm/year fixed effects, while noting selection and causation limits.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions

title: Municipal Debt and Marginal Tax Rates:  Is there a Tax Premium in Asset Prices?
author: Francis A. Longstaff
context: This triplet is estimated using monthly changes in the model-implied marginal tax rate τt (constructed from weekly MSI and municipal swap data, taking the first estimated τt each month) regressed on monthly financial variables. The sample covers Aug 1, 2001–Jun 18, 2008 (U.S. municipal swap/VRDO markets), and explanatory variables include S&P 500 returns and Treasury bond returns; the institutional setting is U.S. tax-exempt municipal debt under progressive federal/state/local taxation, including 2007–08 market disruptions.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Are Stocks Really Less Volatile in the Long Run?
author: Lubos Pastor, Robert F. Stambaugh
context: This paper empirically evaluates long‑horizon volatility of the U.S. equity market using annual real log returns from 1802–2007 (and supplementary quarterly data 1952Q1–2006Q4). The unit of observation is market returns and associated predictors (dividend yield, bond yield, term spread) plus CFO survey responses; the setting is the U.S. public equity market and mutual‑fund target‑date allocation practice. The study examines how parameter uncertainty and imperfect predictors affect predictive variance and long‑horizon portfolio implications.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: What Segments Equity Markets?
author: Geert Bekaert, Campbell R. Harvey, Christian Lundblad, Stephan Siegel
context: The study analyzes monthly and annual country‑level data (primarily 1980–2005, with monthly series from 1973–2005) for 50 countries (developed and emerging). The unit is the country‑year industry‑weighted earnings‑yield differential (SEG) across 38 industries. The context covers liberalization of capital accounts and equity markets, trade openness, institutional quality and market development, and global risk episodes (e.g., the 1997–98 crises). The authors link de jure openness, political/institutional indicators and global risk factors to observed valuation segmentation using panel and time‑series econometric models.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Does Corporate Governance Matter in Competitive Industries?
author: Xavier Giroud, Holger M. Mueller
context: Using U.S. firm-year panel data (Compustat) from 1976–1995, the paper studies how staggered passage of 30 state business combination (BC) laws (primarily 1985–1991) affected firm performance. Units are U.S. firms defined by state of incorporation and state of location, with industry competition measured by HHIs (3-digit SIC). BC laws constrained hostile takeovers by moratoria on business combinations; identification exploits variation in adoption timing and incorporation-location mismatches, with event dates from contemporary newspaper reports.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

title: Financial Regulation, Financial Globalization and the Synchronization of Economic Activity
author: Sebnem Kalemli-Ozcan, Elias Papaioannou, José Luis Peydró
context: This paper uses bilateral annual data on international bank assets and liabilities from the BIS for 18 advanced economies over 1978–2006 (153+ country-pair observations). The unit of observation is country-pair–year. It studies how de-facto banking integration and a de-jure regulatory harmonization index (timing of transposition of 27 EU FSAP Directives) affect business-cycle synchronization among developed countries, controlling for pair fixed effects and common shocks; analyses focus on tranquil pre-2007 periods and exploit within-pair changes and staggered legislative adoption.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; IV

title: Risk Shifting and Mutual Fund Performance
author: Jennifer Huang, Clemens Sialm, Hanjiang Zhang
context: Using holdings and return data for 2,335 actively managed U.S. equity mutual funds (CRSP and Thomson) over 1983–2006, the paper studies how changes in portfolio holdings volatility (holdings vs. past realized volatility) relate to subsequent fund performance. The institutional setting is U.S. mutual funds with periodic SEC disclosures, fee structures, and flow-performance incentives; analyses exploit cross-sectional and time-series variation in fund characteristics (expenses, size, age, family) and holdings to assess agency-driven risk shifting versus timing ability.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: When are Analyst Recommendation Changes Influential?
author: Roger K. Loh, René M. Stulz
context: Using U.S. analyst recommendation revisions from Thomson I/B/E/S (1993–2006), the paper studies individual analyst recommendation changes (firm–analyst observations) and their short-run impact on firm stock returns and the information environment. The sample excludes recommendations clustered with firm news (earnings, guidance) and NASD 2711 reissues. The institutional setting is U.S. equity markets, with explicit tests for regulatory breaks (Reg FD from Sep 2000 and the Global Analyst Settlement from 2003). Outcomes include three-day CARs relative to size/BM/momentum benchmarks, volatility, turnover, and subsequent analyst forecasts.
identification_methods: event studies; other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Land and Credit: A Study of the Political Economy of Banking in the United States in the Early 20th Century
author: Raghuram G. Rajan, Rodney Ramcharan
context: The paper studies county-level banking and credit in the United States in the early 20th century (primarily 1890–1930, focusing on 1920 and 1930). The unit of observation is U.S. counties; outcomes include banks per capita, mortgage interest rates, indebtedness and mortgage lending. The setting leverages variation in agricultural land distribution (farm-size Gini), tenancy, crop-lien and chartering institutions (state vs. national banks, unit-banking laws) and geographic factors (rainfall, distance to state capital) to assess how landed interests shaped local financial development.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: World Markets for Mergers and Acquisitions
author: Isil Erel, Rose C. Liao, Michael S. Weisbach
context: This empirical study analyzes 56,978 cross-border mergers announced worldwide between 1990 and 2007, using firm-, deal-, and country-level data on completed M&A, stock-market indices, and real exchange rates. Units include country-pair-year observations, individual transactions, and public-firm subsamples across developed and developing countries. The setting encompasses international M&A markets, variations in currencies, country stock-market performance, and institutional features (legal origin, investor protection, accounting quality), exploiting temporal variation to assess how valuation and wealth effects drive cross-border acquisition patterns.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; event studies; other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Why Did Some Banks Perform Better During the Credit Crisis? A Cross-Country Study of the Impact of Governance and Regulation
author: Andrea Beltratti, René M. Stulz
context: This paper analyzes cross-country variation in buy-and-hold stock returns for 98 large deposit-taking banks (assets >$50bn) across about 20 countries during the 2007–2008 global credit crisis (main window July 2007–Dec 2008 and the Lehman month Sep 12–Oct 10, 2008). title: The Composition Matters: Capital Inflows and Liquidity Crunch during a Global Economic Crisis
author: Hui Tong, Shang-Jin Wei

context: This paper studies 3,823 listed manufacturing firms in 24 emerging economies during the 2007–09 global financial crisis, focusing on stock returns from July 31, 2007 to Dec 31, 2008 and an event study around Lehman’s Sep 15, 2008 collapse. title: Mutual Fund Tax Clienteles
author: Clemens Sialm, Laura Starks
treatment: Reduction in dividend and long-term capital gains taxes
context: This paper studies US actively-managed domestic equity mutual funds over 1997–2006 (6,811 fund-year observations across 1,348 funds), using fund-year and quarterly fund-position observations. It links fund tax clienteles—measured as the share of assets in defined-contribution (DC) retirement plans from Pensions & Investments—to fund distributions, holdings, and performance (CRSP and Thomson holdings). The institutional setting includes pass-through mutual fund taxation and the 2003 JGTRRA dividend/capital-gains tax cuts, which the authors exploit as a policy shock to examine how manager behavior responds to changes in investor tax status.

title: Banking Deregulations, Financing Constraints, and Firm Entry Size
author: William Kerr, Ramana Nanda
context: Using the US Census Bureau Longitudinal Business Database (annual establishment-level data, 1976 onward; entrants roughly 1977–1996), the paper examines state-level interstate branch‑banking deregulations (staggered across US states, 1970s–mid‑1990s) and their effect on entry rates of private‑sector establishments. The triplet focuses on interstate (not intrastate) reforms and exploits event‑study/staggered‑adoption variation with annual lead/lag indicators (10 years before and after reform), controlling for state and year fixed effects, clustering standard errors by state, and weighting states by pre‑period startup employment.

context: This empirical study uses US Census Bureau Longitudinal Business Database establishment-level employment data (annual, 1976 onward, focusing on entrants roughly 1977–1996) to examine how state-level intrastate and interstate branch-banking deregulations (1970s–mid-1990s), enacted at different times across US states, affected entry sizes and early growth of new private‑sector establishments (startups). title: How Do Retirees Value Life Annuities? Evidence from Public Employees
author: John Chalmers, Jonathan Reuter
context: This paper studies 32,060 retirements in the Oregon Public Employees Retirement System (PERS) from January 1990 to June 2002. Each retiree (ages roughly 50–70) chose between a total life annuity and a lump-sum; PERS computes benefits using DC, DB, and DCDB formulas with fixed conversion factors, making PERS annuities substantially more generous than private TIAA annuities. The institutional setting includes 6% employee contributions, regular/variable account investments, no default payout, and time-series variation from 10-year Treasury yields and equity-market shocks (S&P, NASDAQ, VIX).

title: Bankruptcy and the Collateral Channel
author: Efraim Benmelech, Nittai K. Bergman
context: This paper studies U.S. airlines during 1994–2007 using tranche-level transactions in aircraft-backed securities (ETCs/EETCs/PTCs). The unit of observation is tranche transactions (127 tranches, 18,327 trades) issued by airlines; collateral is identified via aircraft serial numbers and model types. The institutional setting features Section 1110 protections, Chapter 11/7 bankruptcies, liquidity facilities/credit enhancers, and relatively illiquid secondary markets for used aircraft. Identification exploits time-series variation in airline bankruptcies and cross-sectional overlap between tranche collateral and bankrupt airlines’ fleets to estimate effects on credit spreads.

title: Stressed not Frozen: The Fed Funds Market in the Financial Crisis
author: Gara Afonso, Anna Kovner, Antoinette Schoar
context: This paper studies US overnight federal funds transactions around the 2008 financial crisis, focusing on the Lehman Brothers bankruptcy (September 15, 2008) and subsequent policy actions (AIG bailout Sept 16, IOR Oct 9, CPP Oct 14). Using proprietary Fedwire transaction-level data aggregated to bank holding companies (daily borrower- and lender-level observations; ~360 borrowers, ~274 lenders) from April 1, 2008–Feb 28, 2009, it examines how bank size, performance (NPLs, ROA), and pre-crisis repo reliance affected fed funds access, rates, and counterparties within the institutional setting of Fed facilities, the discount window, and a disrupted repo market.

title: Corporate Bond Default Risk: A 150-Year Perspective
author: Kay Giesecke, Francis A. Longstaff, Stephen Schaefer, Ilya Strebulaev
context: This paper analyzes U.S. corporate bond default rates and credit spreads for nonfinancial firms using a newly compiled annual value-weighted dataset covering 1866–2008. The primary unit is the annual value-weighted default rate (par value) of domestic nonfinancial corporate bonds; auxiliary series include aggregate stock returns, interest rates, corporate yields, and NBER recession indicators. Analyses study long-run determinants of defaults, clustering of default cycles, and whether spreads price realized default losses.

title: Measurement Errors in Investment Equations
author: Heitor Almeida, Murillo Campello, Antonio F. Galvao Jr.
context: This paper examines measurement error in firm-level investment equations using a COMPUSTAT panel of U.S. manufacturing firms (1970–2005). The unit of observation is the firm-year; the study focuses on how measurement error in Tobin’s q (average vs. marginal q) biases estimates of investment–cash‑flow sensitivities. The authors compare higher‑order‑moment (Erickson‑Whited) estimators with IV strategies (OLS‑IV, Arellano–Bond GMM), account for firm fixed effects, autocorrelation, and heteroskedasticity, and evaluate implications for financing‑friction interpretations of investment.

context: This paper analyzes U.S. quarterly data from Q4 1952 through Q4 2008, using six Fama–French size×book-to-market portfolio returns together with aggregate U.S. consumption, stock-market wealth, and labor-income series. title: Stronger Risk Controls, Lower Risk: Evidence from U.S. Bank Holding Companies
author: Andrew Ellul, Vijay Yerramilli
context: This estimate uses the 74 largest publicly‑listed U.S. bank holding companies and tests whether a bank’s Risk Management Index in 2006 predicts its off‑balance‑sheet derivative trading during the crisis years. The treatment is RMI in 2006; the outcome is the gross notional value (in $ billion) of derivative contracts held for trading in 2007–2008. The result comes from cross‑sectional regressions of crisis‑year outcomes on RMI_2006 controlling for 2006 bank characteristics and year fixed effects, using FR Y‑9C and SEC filings.

title: The Capital Structure Decisions of New Firms
author: Alicia M. Robb, David T. Robinson
context: This study analyzes capital-structure choices of U.S. startups identified at founding in 2004 using the Kauffman Firm Survey (≈4,928 firms; analytic sample ≈3,972) followed through 2007. The unit is the nascent firm (and primary owner), observed across industries and MSAs. The paper exploits cross-sectional and short-panel variation—including Saiz (housing supply elasticity) at the MSA level and state bankruptcy homestead exemptions—to infer how pledgeable collateral and credit conditions affect initial bank debt, trade credit, insider funding, and subsequent survival, employment, and profit growth.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Liquidity Management and Corporate Investment During a Financial Crisis
author: Murillo Campello, Erasmo Giambona, John R. Graham, Campbell R. Harvey
context: This paper studies firms' liquidity management and planned real spending during the 2008–2009 global financial crisis (surveys conducted Q1 2009 with follow-ups in Q2 2009 and June 2010). title: The Effects of Stock Lending on Security Prices:  An Experiment
author: Steven N. Kaplan, Tobias J. Moskowitz, Berk A. Sensoy
context: This paper reports a randomized lending experiment with a large anonymous money manager (> $15bn AUM) who randomly made two-thirds of its high-loan-fee U.S. small- and mid-cap equity holdings available for securities lending and withheld the remainder. The intervention ran in two phases: Sept 5–18, 2008 (recall Sept 18–Oct 3) and June 5–Sept 30, 2009, covering U.S. exchange-traded stocks and occurring amid the 2008–09 crisis and after SEC Rule 204T; outcomes are stock loan fees, returns, volatility, skewness, and bid-ask spreads at the individual-stock level.

title: How did increased competition affect credit ratings?
author: Bo Becker, Todd Milbourn
context: This empirical study examines how the rise of Fitch as a third credit rater affected incumbent ratings quality in the U.S. corporate bond market, using issuer- and issue-level data from roughly 1995–2006 (with discussion through 2007). Units of observation include individual bond ratings, firm (issuer) ratings, bond trades, and 2-digit NAICS industry-year cells. Identification exploits cross-industry variation in Fitch’s market share, industry/year and bond/firm fixed effects, and institutional details such as the issuer‑paid revenue model, NRSRO status, and Fitch’s 2005 inclusion in the Lehman index.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Snow and Leverage
author: Xavier Giroud, Holger M. Mueller, Alex Stomper, Arne Westerkamp
context: This empirical study examines 115 highly leveraged Austrian ski hotels that underwent debt restructurings between 1998 and 2005 (with a control sample of 2,095 hotels). The Austrian Hotel- and Tourism Bank (AHTB) mediated restructurings under eligibility rules for “structurally important” hotels; data include pre- and post-restructuring accounting and local weather. The authors use two-year Unexpected Snow (relative to a ten-year average) to distinguish liquidity versus strategic distress and to instrument reductions in leverage, estimating effects on ROA, margins, costs, and sales.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: The European Union, the Euro, and Equity Market Integration
author: Geert Bekaert, Campbell R. Harvey, Christian T. Lundblad, Stephan Siegel
context: Using monthly firm-level data (1980–2007) for 33 European countries, the paper studies bilateral country-pair-year equity valuation differentials (industry earnings yields) to evaluate how EU membership and Euro adoption affected cross-border equity market integration. Units are country-pairs constructed from value-weighted industry portfolios. The institutional setting is European market liberalization, regulatory harmonization, Maastricht/Euro accession, and varying exchange-rate regimes. The analysis exploits time variation in membership, country-pair and year effects, and instruments (distance to Brussels) while examining channels like trade, FDI, regulation, and interest-rate convergence.
identification_methods: DiD; IV; other panel regressions

title: Capital-Market Effects of Securities Regulation: Prior Conditions, Implementation, and Enforcement
author: Hans B. Christensen, Luzi Hail, Christian Leuz
context: The paper studies firm-level stock-market liquidity across 26 European countries from 2001–2011 (about 112,260 firm-quarter observations, ~4,846 firms), exploiting staggered national transposition dates of two EU directives—the Market Abuse Directive (MAD) and the Transparency Directive (TPD)—that tightened insider-trading and disclosure rules. It analyzes regulated versus unregulated market listings, constructs a liquidity factor from bid-ask spreads, price impact, zero returns, and trading costs, and examines heterogeneity by prior regulatory quality, supervisory powers, penalties, and regulator staffing while controlling for other FSAP directives.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; PSM; other panel regressions

The paper studies firm-level stock-market liquidity across 26 European countries from 2001–2011 (about 112,260 firm-quarter observations, ~4,846 firms), exploiting staggered national transposition dates of two EU directives—the Market Abuse Directive (MAD) and the Transparency Directive (TPD)—that tightened insider-trading and disclosure rules. title: Margin-Based Asset Pricing and Deviations from the Law of One Price
author: Nicolae Gârleanu, Lasse Heje Pedersen
context: In the paper’s theoretical continuous-time general-equilibrium model, heterogeneous agents (relatively risk-averse and risk-tolerant investors) trade risky securities that have security-specific margin (haircut) requirements. Negative shocks to fundamentals (falls in dividends/aggregate consumption) reduce leveraged agents’ wealth and raise their shadow cost of funding, causing margin constraints to bind and thereby lowering collateralized risk-free rates while raising risk premia and Sharpe ratios, particularly for high-margin securities.
identification_methods: others

title: Does Aggregated Returns Disclosure Increase Portfolio Risk-Taking?
author: John Beshears, James J. Choi, David Laibson, Brigitte C. Madrian
context: This paper evaluates whether aggregating investment-return disclosures affects portfolio risk-taking using randomized experiments. Primary evidence comes from a year‑long online field RCT (summer 2008–2009) in which 597 U.S. adult participants allocated $325 among four real mutual funds (U.S. equity, international equity, bonds, money market) and were randomized to weekly vs biannual return viewings, portfolio‑ vs asset‑level reporting, and historical‑return graph treatments. The authors supplement this with laboratory and post‑lab experiments (2013) on students and mixed samples to probe mechanisms and robustness.
identification_methods: RCT

title: Adoptive Expectations: Rising Sons in Japanese Family Firms
author: Vikas Mehrotra, Randall Morck, Jungwook Shim, Yupana Wiwattanakantang
context: This paper studies nearly the population of Japanese non-financial firms that listed between 1949–1970 (sample ~1,367 firms) and follows firm-year data from 1962 through 2000. It examines intergenerational succession events and performance for founders, biological heirs, and non-blood (adopted/son-in-law) heirs in postwar Japan, emphasizing institutional practices of adult adoption (yōshi) and arranged marriage that shape succession. Using firm-level accounting, ownership, board, and market data, the authors assess whether variation in succession and family structure causally affects profitability, valuation, and growth.
identification_methods: IV; event studies; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: The Short of It: Investor Sentiment and Anomalies
author: Robert F. Stambaugh, Jianfeng Yu, Yu Yuan
context: This empirical study uses U.S. equity data from July 1965–January 2008 to examine whether market‑wide investor sentiment (the Baker–Wurgler index and alternative consumer sentiment measures) drives mispricing across 11 Fama–French‑adjusted stock‑return anomalies. The unit of analysis is decile‑sorted, value‑weighted portfolios and monthly long‑short strategies constructed from individual firms (U.S. stocks). The setting emphasizes short‑sale impediments and tests if high‑sentiment months are associated with greater overpricing (lower short‑leg returns), controlling for Fama–French factors and macro variables.

title: The Importance of Trust for Investment: Evidence from Venture Capital

title: Are Corporate Default Probabilities Consistent with the Static Tradeoff Theory?
author: Armen Hovakimian, Ayla Kayhan, Sheridan Titman
context: This empirical study analyzes US nonfinancial firms (firm-year observations) from 1985–2008 (46,219 obs), testing whether firm default probabilities (S&P issuer ratings and Moody’s KMV EDF) reflect static tradeoff predictions. Using Compustat/CRSP financials, simulated marginal tax rates, and Moody’s EDF, the authors examine how firm size, asset tangibility, R&D, profitability, and market shocks relate to default risk, account for selection into ratings (visibility instruments: NYSE listing, S&P indexes, industry-rated share), and exploit panel variation and regime-switching to assess dynamic responses to shocks.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: The Effect of Providing Peer Information on Retirement Savings Decisions
author: John Beshears, James J. Choi, David Laibson, Brigitte C. Madrian, Katherine L. Milkman
context: A randomized field experiment conducted in 2008 at a large U.S. manufacturing firm (~15,000 employees) evaluates how disseminating age‑bracket peer 401(k) information affects individual savings choices. Between July and September 2008, non‑participants and low‑saving employees aged 20–69 received Quick Enrollment or Easy Escalation mailings that were randomly assigned to include no peer data or peer participation rates for 5‑ or 10‑year age brackets. The design exploits variation in union status, automatic‑enrollment defaults, and employer match thresholds to assess enrollment and contribution responses.
identification_methods: RCT

title: Mutual Fund Performance and the Incentive to Generate Alpha
author: Diane Del Guercio, Jonathan Reuter
context: This paper uses U.S. retail mutual fund data from 1992–2004 to examine how distribution channels shape incentives to generate alpha. The unit of analysis is actively managed domestic equity mutual funds (fund-months), classified as direct-sold or broker-sold using FRC and CRSP share-class data. The institutional setting is the U.S. mutual fund market where broker-distributed funds bundle financial advice (and 12b-1/revenue-sharing) while direct-sold funds provide unbundled portfolio management; analyses exploit cross-sectional and panel variation in flows, family policies, and performance.

author: Alon Brav, Wei Jiang, Hyunseob Kim

context: This paper studies US equity markets from January 1998 to December 2010, using daily CRSP data on NYSE, AMEX and Nasdaq stocks and 48 Fama–French industries. title: The Out of Sample" Performance of Long-run Risk Models"
author: Wayne E. Ferson, Suresh K. Nallareddy, Biqin Xie
context: This paper evaluates long-run risk asset-pricing models for the United States using annual data spanning 1931–2009. Units of analysis include aggregate consumption and dividend series and excess returns on portfolios (size, book-to-market, momentum deciles), the market portfolio, and bonds of varying maturities and credit quality. It compares stationary and cointegrated Bansal–Yaron–style specifications, estimating parameters (via GMM and related methods) with lagged state variables (risk-free rate, log price/dividend) and rolling out-of-sample prediction to assess pricing of unconditional expected returns and risk premiums.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Equity-Holding Institutional Lenders:  Do they Receive Better Terms?
author: Jongha Lim, Bernadette A. Minton, Michael S. Weisbach
context: This paper analyzes U.S. leveraged loan syndicates during 1997–2007, using loan-tranche level observations for non‑financial publicly listed firms. title: Country Size, Currency Unions, and International Asset Returns

context: This paper examines how country size and currency unions affect international asset returns across developed economies (27 OECD countries) using data from roughly 1980–2007 (with subperiods 1984–1990, 1991–1998, 1998–2007). title: The Cost of Friendship
author: Paul Gompers, Vladimir Mukharlyamov, Yuhai Xuan
context: This paper studies U.S. venture capital syndication during 1975–2003 using 3,510 individual venture capitalists and 11,895 portfolio-company investments. Units of analysis are person-investments and VC dyads (founding and follow-on partners). The institutional setting is private U.S. venture investing, with hand-collected biographic data (education, ethnicity, prior employers), and success measured by IPO outcomes. The authors examine how ability- versus affinity-based homophily shapes partner selection and causally affects investment success, constructing counterfactual potential partners, controlling for deal observables, and assessing post-investment treatment effects.

title: Wrongful Discharge Laws and Innovation
author: Viral V. Acharya, Ramin P. Baghai, Krishnamurthy V. Subramanian
context: This study analyzes the effect of state-level wrongful discharge laws (public-policy, implied-contract, and especially the good-faith exception) on firm innovation and entrepreneurship in the U.S. using firm-year data from 1971–1999. Exploiting staggered, precedent-driven adoption of these common-law exceptions across states, the authors link USPTO patents (counts and citations) matched to Compustat firms, patents per employee/R&D, and Business Dynamics Statistics on new establishments and job creation to identify changes in innovative effort and start-up formation.

title: Speculative Betas
author: Harrison Hong, David Sraer
context: This paper studies U.S. equity markets (monthly data, mainly 1970–2010; analyst forecasts 1981–2010; short-interest 1988–2009) using individual stocks and 20 beta-sorted portfolios. It links stock-level outcomes (returns, turnover, short interest, analyst forecast dispersion) to aggregate disagreement and economic uncertainty. The institutional setting emphasizes heterogeneous investors (short-sale–constrained mutual funds vs unconstrained arbitrageurs/hedge funds) and short-sale constraints that may generate speculative overpricing of high‑beta stocks; aggregate disagreement is proxied by beta-weighted analyst LTG dispersion and Bloom’s plant-level uncertainty series.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Arbitrage Asymmetry and the Idiosyncratic Volatility Puzzle
author: Robert F. Stambaugh, Jianfeng Yu, Yu Yuan
context: This paper studies U.S. equity markets from August 1965 to January 2011, using individual common stocks and value-weighted portfolios to examine how idiosyncratic volatility relates to average returns. The authors combine 11 documented return anomalies to construct a cross-sectional mispricing ranking, adjust returns with Fama–French three-factor regressions, and use the Baker–Wurgler investor-sentiment index (and macro controls) to study time-varying mispricing and arbitrage asymmetry driven by short-sale impediments and arbitrage risk.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Do Acquisitions Relieve Target Firms' Financial Constraints?
author: Isil Erel, Yeejin Jang, Michael S. Weisbach
context: This estimate focuses on acquiring firms in the paper's sample of European target acquisitions (completed 2001–2008). title: Asset Quality Misrepresentation by Financial Intermediaries: Evidence from RMBS Market
author: Tomasz Piskorski, Amit Seru, James Witkin

title: Learning about CEO Ability and Stock Return Volatility
author: Yihui Pan, Tracy Yue Wang, Michael S. Weisbach
context: This paper examines market learning about CEO ability using 1,873 CEO turnovers at 1,582 U.S. publicly traded firms between 1992 and 2006 (volatility data through 2009). The unit of analysis is firm-months and firm-CEO pairs, using monthly realized, idiosyncratic, and option-implied volatilities. A theoretical Bayesian learning model (dividend/earnings GBM, efficient markets) motivates tests; empirical analyses compare exogenous (death/retirement) vs forced turnovers and control for post-turnover actions, firm characteristics, and calendar effects.

title: 'Lucas' In The Laboratory
author: Elena Asparouhova, Peter Bossaerts, Nilanjan Roy, William Zame
context: Laboratory asset-market experiments run in multiple sessions at Caltech, UCLA and the University of Utah, with human subjects trading two long‑lived assets (a risky “Tree” with i.i.d. title: The Twilight Zone: OTC Regulatory Regimes and Market Quality
author: Ulf Brüggemann, Aditya Kaul, Christian Leuz, Ingrid M. Werner
context: This paper studies U.S. over-the-counter (OTC) equity markets from January 2001 through October 2010 using a panel of ≈10,583 domestic firms (firm-months ≈955,716). It exploits variation across OTC trading venues (NASDAQ Bulletin Board, OTC Pink tiers, Grey Market), firms’ SEC filing status, inclusion in securities manuals, and state “blue sky” merit-review regimes — including several Pink Sheets regulatory changes — to estimate effects on market quality (liquidity and crash risk). Identification leverages within-firm venue and reporting-status transitions, regulatory reforms, and cross-state institutional differences.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; PSM; other panel regressions

title: The Joint Cross Section of Stocks and Options

treatment: Informed traders trading first in option market
context: This study examines U.S. firm-level option and equity markets from January 1996 through December 2011, using monthly observations on option-implied volatilities (30-day, delta 0.5) from OptionMetrics and stock returns and characteristics from CRSP/Compustat. title: Housing Collateral and Entrepreneurship
author: Martin C. Schmalz, David A. Sraer, David Thesmar
context: This empirical paper examines how housing collateral affects entrepreneurship in France by exploiting regional house-price growth in the 1990s (primarily 1992–1997) and firm outcomes for entrepreneurs who started businesses in 1998 (tracked through 1999–2005), along with individual transitions from the 1990–2002 Labor Force Survey. Key data sources are the SINE survey, tax files, notary house-price series, and INSEE business registries.

title: Have Financial Markets Become More Informative?
author: Jennie Bai, Thomas Philippon, Alexi Savov
context: Using U.S. firm-year data (primarily S&P 500 non‑financial firms) over 1960–2014 (R&D data from 1972 onward), the paper operationalizes aggregate efficiency as the cross‑sectional variance of the manager’s conditional expectation of future cash flows. Empirically it bounds this unobserved aggregate efficiency below by the predicted variation of future earnings from firm investment (R&D and CAPX) and above by the cross‑sectional dispersion of investment; increases in these measures are interpreted as rises in aggregate efficiency.

title: The Price of Political Uncertainty: Theory and Evidence from the Option Market
author: Bryan Kelly, Lubos Pastor, Pietro Veronesi
context: This paper studies how political uncertainty is priced in equity option markets by examining options whose maturities span national elections and economically-relevant global summits. It uses OptionMetrics and realized-variance data for index options across 20 countries (option samples mainly 2002–2012, with S&P 500 data back to 1990) and summit windows concentrated in 2007–2011. The unit of observation is country-level equity index options; analysis exploits scheduled event timing, poll spreads, and country-level macro indicators (GDP growth, IMF forecasts, CLI, recent market returns).

title: Central Clearing and Collateral Demand
author: Darrell Duffie, Martin Scheicher, Guillaume Vuillemey
context: This paper empirically analyzes how expanded margin requirements and central clearing affect collateral demand in the single-name CDS market using a global DTCC Trade Information Warehouse snapshot as of December 30, 2011. The unit of observation is bilateral CDS exposures across 184 reference entities (primarily European and American financial and sovereign names) and 885 anonymized counterparties (distinguishing 14 dealers and customers). title: Can Taxes Shape an Industry? Evidence from the Implementation of the “Amazon Tax”
author: Brian Baugh, Itzhak Ben-David, Hoonsuk Park
context: This paper studies how state laws requiring Amazon to collect sales tax (“Amazon Tax”) affected consumer purchases. Using transaction-level data from an online account aggregator for about 275,000 U.S. households from January 2011–May 2015 across 19 treated and 31 control states, the authors analyze monthly tax-exclusive Amazon spending around staggered state implementation dates (2012–2015). title: Do ETFs Increase Volatility?
author: Itzhak Ben-David, Francesco Franzoni, Rabih Moussawi
context: The paper studies U.S. equity markets from roughly 2000–2012, focusing on stocks (S&P 500 and Russell 3000 constituents) and 660 U.S. ‘‘plain vanilla’’ equity ETFs traded on U.S. exchanges. title: Asset Pricing with Countercyclical Household Consumption Risk
author: George M. Constantinides, Anisha Ghosh
context: This paper analyzes U.S. household consumption risk and asset prices, combining household-quarter consumption from the CEX (1982:Q1–2009:Q4) with aggregate prices/dividends (CRSP, 1929–2009). The setting is an incomplete-consumption-insurance economy with heterogeneous labor-income shocks and Epstein–Zin recursive preferences; the authors estimate a structural model to link persistent, countercyclical left-skewed idiosyncratic consumption shocks to time-series and cross-sectional asset pricing facts across business cycles.

title: Retail Financial Advice: Does One Size Fit All?
author: Stephen Foerster, Juhani T. Linnainmaa, Brian T. Melzer, Alessandro Previtero

title: A Taxonomy of Anomalies and their Trading Costs
author: Robert Novy-Marx, Mihail Velikov
context: This paper empirically evaluates the post-1963 U.S. equity anomaly literature using monthly and annual stock-level data (primarily July 1963–December 2013, with some analyses from 1973 onward). Units are individual U.S. publicly traded firms across the market-cap spectrum. The authors estimate transaction costs (effective bid–ask spreads via Hasbrouck’s Bayesian/Gibbs estimator), compute factor alphas and portfolio performance for 23 anomalies (size, value, momentum, PEAD, etc.), and analyze turnover and trading-cost mitigation (low-cost universe, staggered rebalancing, buy/hold spread) in the U.S. market context.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions; event studies; others

title: Spare Tire? Stock Markets, Banking Crises, and Economic Recoveries
author: Ross Levine, Chen Lin, Wensi Xie
context: This paper examines how pre-crisis shareholder protection shapes firms' responses to systemic banking crises across 36 countries from 1990–2011. Using firm-level panel data on publicly listed manufacturing firms (≈3,600 firms; ≈23,000 firm-years), the authors link Laeven and Valencia’s crisis start dates to Djankov et al.’s Anti-self-dealing index to study profits, employment, equity issuances, and investment efficiency. The institutional setting contrasts countries’ shareholder-protection legal infrastructure and stock-market financing as a potential “spare tire” when bank credit contracts during systemic crises.
identification_methods: DiD; other panel regressions

title: Labor-Force Heterogeneity and Asset Prices: the Importance of Skilled Labor
author: Frederico Belo, Xiaoji Lin, Jun Li, Xiaofei Zhao
context: This paper examines how industry-level labor-skill heterogeneity shapes firm risk and asset prices using U.S. publicly traded firms (mainly 1991–2012, with a longer 1963–2012 extension via imputed skills) and G7 international data (1992–2012). Units are firm-year observations and annually rebalanced July–June portfolios. Industries are classified by the fraction of high-skilled occupations (DOT SVP and BLS OES). Empirical tests relate firms’ hiring rates to future stock returns under a production-investment model that assumes higher labor adjustment costs for high-skilled workers.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions; others

title: Public Audit Oversight and Reporting Credibility: Evidence from the PCAOB Inspection Regime
author: Brandon Gipper, Christian Leuz, Mark Maffett
outcome: Earnings response coefficient for profitable firms
context: This analysis focuses on U.S. issuers (clients of large U.S. auditors) compared to U.S.-traded cross-listed foreign firms as controls during the PCAOB rollout (limited Big Four inspections in 2003 and full inspections in 2004). title: Dividend Dynamics, Learning, and Expected Stock Index Returns
author: Ravi Jagannathan, Binying Liu
outcome: Variation in annual stock index returns
context: This paper studies U.S. aggregate stock-index dividend and earnings dynamics using S&P500 annual data from 1946–2016 (training pre-1975; out-of-sample 1975–2016). The unit is the aggregate market (S&P500) with observed prices, cash dividends, and earnings; the authors model corporate payout policy, inflation, and a persistent latent component, assume investors (Kreps anticipated-utility learning) update beliefs about dividend-process parameters, and embed learning into an Epstein–Zin long-run risks asset-pricing framework to assess effects on expected stock-index returns.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Can't Pay or Won't Pay? Unemployment, Negative Equity, and Strategic Default
author: Kristopher Gerardi, Kyle F. Herkenhoff, Lee E. Ohanian, Paul S. Willen
context: This paper analyzes U.S. homeowners using the 2009, 2011, and 2013 PSID housing supplements to study mortgage default decisions after the housing bust. The unit of analysis is primary-residence mortgagor households (ages 24–65) matched to self-reported mortgage balances, home values, income, consumption, employment and health status across states. The setting examines negative equity, unemployment and disability shocks in 2009–2013 and leverages state-level house-price variation and individual job/disability shocks to identify causal effects on default and strategic walk-away behavior.

title: Enlarging the Contracting Space: Collateral Menus, Access to Credit, and Economic Activity
author: Murillo Campello, Mauricio Larrain
context: This paper studies firm‑level outcomes for manufacturers in Romania and nine other Eastern European countries over 1996–2005, exploiting the staggered adoption of collateral‑law reforms (Romania’s Law 99 in 2000; Poland 1998; Latvia 1999; others reformed earlier or not). Using Amadeus firm data and sectoral indices of movable vs. immovable asset intensity, the authors leverage the legal introduction of non‑possessory security interests and electronic registries for movable assets to identify effects on borrowing, cash holdings, investment, employment, productivity, and sectoral reallocation.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions; others

title: Enlarging the Contracting Space: Collateral Menus, Access to Credit, and Economic Activity
author: Murillo Campello, Mauricio Larrain
context: Focusing on economy-wide reallocation, the paper documents changes in the share of aggregate fixed assets allocated to sectors intensive in movable assets in Romania over 1996–2005, around Romania’s Law 99 (effective 2000). It measures country-level sector shares of fixed capital before and after the collateral-menu-enlarging reform and reports an increase from 37% to 52% for those sectors; similar pre/post patterns are shown for Latvia (reform 1999) and Poland (reform 1998). Units are sectoral shares of aggregate fixed assets, tied to the introduction of non-possessory security interests for movables.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions; others

title: Overconfidence And Preferences For Competition
author: Ernesto Reuben, Paola Sapienza, Luigi Zingales
context: This study follows the 2008 MBA cohort at the University of Chicago Booth School. In fall 2006 entrants completed an incentivized lab experiment measuring preferences for competition, overconfidence, and risk aversion; administrative job-offer data at graduation (2008) and a 2015 follow-up provide incomes, industries, and bonuses. The U.S. setting focuses on high-pay, pay-for-performance careers (finance and consulting versus other industries), comparing guaranteed hiring bonuses to realized performance-based compensation seven years later to assess how measured traits relate to earnings and career trajectories.

title: Specialization in Bank Lending: Evidence from Exporting Firms

treatment: Increase in firm exports to a country

context: This paper studies bank specialization in lending across export markets using matched bank-loan and customs data for all Peruvian firms during 1994–2010, exploiting monthly loan-level data from the regulator (SBS) and firm-level export shipments. The authors leverage cross-country export demand shocks (country GDP growth and real exchange rates) and the 2008 international capital-flow reversal (banks’ foreign-liability exposure) to isolate demand and supply effects in a bank-dependent Peruvian economy.

title: How Crashes Develop:  Intradaily Volatility and Crash Evolution
author: David S. Bates
treatment: Higher diffusive volatility and frequent intradaily jumps
context: This paper uses 15-minute S&P 500 futures transactions from the CME (1983–2008; out-of-sample tests 2009–2013) to study how major daily crashes develop. The unit of observation is intradaily and overnight futures returns (15-minute intervals) and derived realized variance. The institutional setting includes CME trading hours, tick-size changes, price-limit/circuit-breaker rules, and the shift from open-outcry to electronic Globex. The analysis estimates multifactor affine stochastic volatility–jump models to assess whether self-exciting intradaily volatility spikes produce large daily outliers.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; others

title: Why Does Fast Loan Growth Predict Poor Performance for Banks?
author: Rüdiger Fahlenbrach, Robert Prilmeier, René M. Stulz
context: This paper studies U.S. publicly listed depository institutions and bank holding companies (mostly >$2bn assets) from 1972–2013/2014, using Compustat/CRSP/I/B/E/S, Chicago Fed M&A, call reports and FDIC data. title: How Management Risk Affects Corporate Debt
author: Yihui Pan, Tracy Yue Wang, Michael S. Weisbach
context: This paper studies how uncertainty about management affects corporate default risk and debt pricing using U.S. publicly-traded firms (primarily S&P1500) over 1987–2012 (CDS data 2001–2012). The unit of observation is firm-level debt contracts and daily CDS spreads around CEO and CFO turnovers and over executives’ tenures. title: How Does Hedge Fund Activism Reshape Corporate Innovation?
author: Alon Brav, Wei Jiang, Song Ma, Xuan Tian

You are an expert economist.

# Task
Given a context and a treatment–outcome pair, predict the most likely sign of the causal effect.

# Sign Definitions
- '+': The treatment increases the outcome (positive and statistically significant effect).
- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
Using the February 2000 Swedish policy experiment that opened state liquor stores (Systembolaget) on Saturdays in six treated counties (control and buffer counties excluded), the paper analyzes individual-level pawn and mainstream credit behavior and performance. The triplet focuses on low-income young adults ages 20–25 (the cohort that saw the largest effects), using pawnbroker records, credit bureau snapshots, tax/employment registers, crime convictions, and household cash journals in 1999–2001. Legal off‑site purchase age is 20; the reported effect is an increase in loan delinquencies for the 20–25 cohort.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Increased availability of alcohol
Outcome: Loan delinquencies

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Impulsive Consumption and Financial Wellbeing: Evidence from an Increase in the Availability of Alcohol
author: Itzhak Ben-David, Marieke Bos
context: This triplet refers to the Swedish February 2000 policy experiment that opened state retail liquor stores (Systembolaget) on Saturdays in six treatment counties. It concerns individuals aged 20–25 (the legally eligible buyers) and measures the change in total credit balances (pawn plus mainstream credit) using individual-level pawnbroker records and credit-bureau snapshots around 1999–2001, comparing treated and control counties in a pre/post framework.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

title: Are Larger Banks Valued More Highly?
author: Bernadette A. Minton, René M. Stulz, Alvaro G. Taboada
context: This paper studies U.S. publicly traded bank holding companies (171 banks, 1987–2015, with emphasis on the pre‑crisis window 1987–2006) using FRY‑9C and CRSP/Compustat data to assess how market valuation (Tobin’s q and market-to-book) varies with bank asset size—particularly above the Dodd‑Frank enhanced‑supervision threshold ($50 billion in 2010 dollars). The analysis contrasts pre‑ and post‑Global Financial Crisis regulatory regimes (Basel revisions, Dodd‑Frank) and uses cross‑sectional and within‑bank variation to probe TBTF‑related valuation effects.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Real Anomalies
author: Jules H. van Binsbergen, Christian C. Opp
context: This paper studies U.S. publicly traded non-financial firms (NYSE/AMEX/NASDAQ) over roughly 1975–2014, using firm-level monthly returns, book assets, Tobin’s q, and investment to quantify how cross-sectional mispricings (alphas) and their persistence affect real investment. The authors embed CAPM-based empirical alphas into a continuous-time structural model with lumpy, costly adjustment and estimate parameters by GMM, then simulate counterfactuals that eliminate mispricings to measure aggregate surplus losses.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: How Debit Cards Enable the Poor to Save More
author: Pierre Bachas, Paul Gertler, Sean Higgins, Enrique Seira
context: This paper analyzes the phased geographic rollout (2009–2011) of Visa debit cards tied to existing Bansefi savings accounts for urban beneficiaries of Mexico’s conditional cash transfer program Oportunidades/Prospera. It uses administrative transaction and balance data for ~348,000 beneficiary accounts (Jan 2007–Oct 2011) and household surveys (panel 2002–2009/10; trust and payment surveys 2010–2012) to study effects on withdrawals, account balances, consumption, and trust. Institutional context: transfers were paid into fee‑free Bansefi accounts without cards; cards enabled ATM withdrawals and easier balance checks.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Fintech, Regulatory Arbitrage, and the Rise of Shadow Banks
author: Greg Buchak, Gregor Matvos, Tomasz Piskorski, Amit Seru
context: This paper studies U.S. residential mortgage origination from 2007–2015 using HMDA, Fannie/Freddie, and FHA loan data. Units of analysis are individual loans, borrowers, lenders (banks, non‑bank shadow lenders, and online fintech originators), and counties. The institutional setting is the post‑crisis regulatory environment—Basel III capital rules, changes to mortgage servicing rights (MSR) treatment, mortgage‑related lawsuit settlements, and the 2011 OTS closure—together with GSE/FHA financing dynamics and the rise of online origination technology; the authors exploit geographic and temporal variation in regulatory exposure to identify effects.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; IV; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: Monetary Policy and Global Banking
author: Falk Brauning, Victoria Ivashina
context: This paper studies global banks’ cross-currency lending, reserve holdings, and syndicated loan activity from 2000–2016 (U.S. analyses focus on 2008:Q3–2016:Q4), across six major currency areas (U.S., Eurozone, U.K., Japan, Switzerland, Canada). Units of observation include bank-quarter Call Report data, country-currency-quarter BIS claims, and syndicated loan-level bank-firm data. The institutional setting emphasizes central-bank policy rates—particularly interest on excess reserves (IOER)—FX swap markets, and regulatory capital constraints; identification exploits high-frequency FOMC surprises, exchange-rate variation, and panel fixed-effects.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions

title: Risk Management with Supply Contracts
author: Heitor Almeida, Kristine Watson Hankins, Ryan Williams
context: This paper analyzes U.S. non‑financial publicly traded firms (firm‑year observations) from 2003–2010 using Compustat and firms’ 10‑K disclosures to study whether non‑cancelable supply purchase obligations function as hedges versus exchange‑traded commodity derivatives. The primary natural experiment is the mid‑2008 introduction of steel futures on the London Metals Exchange and CME; the authors compare firms with meaningful steel input exposure to matched controls, exploiting panel variation, placebo tests, and post‑2003 SEC disclosure rules for purchase obligations.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; PSM; other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Innovative Originality, Profitability, and Stock Returns
author: David Hirshleifer, Po-Hsuan Hsu, Dongmei Li
context: For this triplet the paper analyzes U.S. publicly traded nonfinancial firms (Compustat–CRSP matched) using USPTO patents through 2006 to construct a five‑year rolling firm-level InnOrig measure. The relation to gross‑margin persistence is estimated in annual Fama–MacBeth cross‑sectional regressions of next‑year gross margin on lagged InnOrig, current and lagged GM, and their interaction, controlling for firm characteristics (sample roughly 1981–2007).
