title: Innovative Originality, Profitability, and Stock Returns
author: David Hirshleifer, Po-Hsuan Hsu, Dongmei Li
context: The paper studies U.S. publicly traded nonfinancial firms matched in Compustat and CRSP, using USPTO patents granted through 2006 to construct a five‑year rolling firm‑level innovative‑originality (InnOrig) measure (patent technology classes). The empirical sample covers roughly 1981–2007. The authors link InnOrig to future profitability (up to five years), gross margins, and abnormal stock returns, controlling for industry, R&D, patents, and other firm characteristics, using patent, accounting, analyst, institutional‑ownership, and monthly return data.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions; event studies; others

title: Making the House a Home: The Stimulative Effect of Home Purchases on Consumption and Investment
author: Efraim Benmelech, Adam Guren, Brian T. Melzer
context: The paper analyzes U.S. homeowners and residential properties primarily over 2001–2013 (permit data 1994–2013) using monthly household panel data from the Consumer Expenditure Survey and property-level BuildFax permit records for ~9 million homes. Focusing on the U.S. housing expansion and collapse including the Great Recession, it estimates how the timing of home purchase transactions affects household spending on home-related durables and improvements. The analysis rests on search frictions and partial irreversibility of renovations, isolating a transaction (purchase) channel distinct from housing-wealth effects.
identification_methods: event studies; other panel regressions

title: Fund Tradeoffs
author: Lubos Pastor, Robert F. Stambaugh, Lucian A. Taylor
context: This paper studies active U.S. equity mutual funds (2,789 funds) over 1979–2014 using quarterly fund-level and holdings data (CRSP, Morningstar, Thomson Reuters). Units are fund-quarter observations within Morningstar 3×3 style sectors. The authors develop an equilibrium model of diseconomies of scale and construct a portfolio-liquidity measure to analyze tradeoffs among AUM, expense ratios, turnover, and diversification, estimating cross-sectional and panel relations while controlling for sector-quarter effects and fund fixed characteristics.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; other time-series regressions

title: Understanding the Rise in Corporate Cash: Precautionary Savings or Foreign Taxes
author: Michael W. Faulkender, Kristine W. Hankins, Mitchell A. Petersen
treatment: Higher share of income earned abroad
context: Using mandatory BEA BE-10/BE-11 survey data from 1998–2008, the paper studies U.S.-based multinational firms (firm-year observations with subsidiary-level detail) to explain the large rise in corporate cash and marketable securities. It contrasts domestic versus foreign cash across countries and industries, exploiting variation in foreign statutory corporate tax rates, the 1997 “check-the-box” tax-classification change, and firm characteristics (R&D intensity and related-party sales) that enable transfer pricing and income shifting.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Flood Risk Belief Heterogeneity and Coastal Home Price Dynamics: Going Under Water?
author: Laura A. Bakkensen, Lint Barrage
context: This paper studies coastal U.S. housing markets, combining a theoretical heterogeneous-beliefs housing model with empirical evidence from a door-to-door household survey (n=187) conducted in Rhode Island in Feb–July 2017 and property-level LiDAR/STORMTOOLS inundation estimates. Units are households/homeowners and individual properties; analysis contrasts coastal (within 400 feet) and non-coastal residents, links belief heterogeneity about 10-year flood risk to sorting, willingness-to-pay, and price dynamics, and calibrates structural simulations using sea-level-rise projections and US flood-insurance (NFIP/FEMA) institutions.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: Do Household Wealth Shocks Affect Productivity? Evidence from Innovative Workers During the Great Recession
author: Shai Bernstein, Timothy McQuade, Richard R. Townsend
context: This paper studies how housing wealth shocks during the Great Recession (pre-period 2005–2007, post 2008–2012) in the U.S. affected individual inventor productivity. Using linked USPTO patent records, CoreLogic deed-level home locations, and firm identifiers, the authors compare innovative workers (patent inventors) living in different zip codes but employed at the same firm and CBSA. The setting leverages zip-code house price declines from 2007–2012 to isolate household balance-sheet shocks’ impact on patent quantity, quality, and firm-level innovation value.

title: Does the Stock Market Make Firms More Productive?
author: Benjamin Bennett, René Stulz, Zexi Wang
context: This study analyzes U.S. publicly listed firms over 1994–2015 (66,341 firm-year observations) to test whether greater stock price informativeness (measured by PIN, PSI and variants) causally increases firm-level total factor productivity (TFP). Identification leverages within-firm panel variation and plausibly exogenous shocks—including brokerage research closures (circa 2000–2007) and S&P 500 additions—along with IV and matched DiD comparisons.

title: Liquidity Regimes and Optimal Dynamic Asset Allocation
author: Pierre Collin-Dufresne, Kent D. Daniel, Mehmet Saǧlam
context: This paper develops a regime-switching portfolio-choice model and implements it using U.S. equity market data and institutional execution records. The authors estimate four-state Markov-switching models on daily value-weighted CRSP market returns from 1967 Q3–2017 Q2, and calibrate state-dependent transaction-cost multipliers using 81,744 large-order executions (VWAP and PoV) on S&P 500 stocks from Jan 2011–Dec 2012. title: Decision Fatigue and Heuristic Analyst Forecasts
author: David Hirshleifer, Yaron Levi, Ben Lourie, Siew Hong Teoh
context: This paper studies sell-side analyst forecasting in U.S. equity markets using I/B/E/S forecast records for 2002–2015. Units are analyst–firm one-year-ahead EPS forecasts issued intra-day (9:00–19:00); the key institutional setting is sequential same-day forecast issuance by analysts who cover multiple firms. The authors measure decision fatigue as the number/order of an analyst’s forecasts per day and analyze effects on forecast accuracy, herding, reissuance, rounding, and investor reactions (3-day market-adjusted returns), controlling for analyst and analyst-day fixed effects and time-of-day.

context: This paper analyzes quarterly country-level data on real GDP growth and realized equity-market volatility for 32 advanced and emerging economies (covering >90% of world GDP) over 1993:Q1–2011:Q2. Units are country-quarter observations. Combining a multi-country Lucas-tree model with empirical factor-augmented VARs and cross-sectional factor estimation, the study assumes a pervasive global ‘real’ growth factor and an additional common ‘financial’ factor in volatilities to separate global versus country-specific shocks and quantify their effects on growth and volatility.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other time-series regressions
question:
# Role
You are an expert economist.

# Task

# Sign Definitions
- '+': The treatment increases the outcome (positive and statistically significant effect).
- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
This paper analyzes quarterly country-level data on real GDP growth and realized equity-market volatility for 32 advanced and emerging economies (covering >90% of world GDP) over 1993:Q1–2011:Q2. Units are country-quarter observations. Combining a multi-country Lucas-tree model with empirical factor-augmented VARs and cross-sectional factor estimation, the study assumes a pervasive global ‘real’ growth factor and an additional common ‘financial’ factor in volatilities to separate global versus country-specific shocks and quantify their effects on growth and volatility.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Real common factor
Outcome: Volatility–growth correlation

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:

- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: The Capitalization of Consumer Financing into Durable Goods Prices
author: Bronson Argyle, Taylor D. Nadauld, Christopher Palmer, Ryan D. Pratt
context: This paper examines how individual consumer credit terms are capitalized into used-car prices in the U.S., using loan-level data on auto originations (2005–2017, concentrated 2011–2017) across hundreds of lenders and commuting zones. The unit is vehicle-level loan transactions (borrowers purchasing used cars). Identification exploits lender-specific, age-based maturity schedules—discrete drops in maximum offered loan maturity when cars nominally age on January 1—generating exogenous variation in maturity and interest terms across otherwise comparable buyers.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; IV; other panel regressions

title: Credit Supply and Housing Speculation
author: Atif Mian, Amir Sufi
context: This study examines U.S. housing markets during 2000–2010, centering on the late‑2003 surge in private‑label mortgage securitization and the 2003–2006 housing boom and subsequent bust. It exploits cross‑sectional and panel variation across lenders, zip codes, and MSAs—using 2002 non‑core‑liability (NCL) exposure—to trace credit‑supply effects on mortgage originations, speculative buyers, prices, construction, and delinquencies. Data sources include HMDA, TransUnion, CoreLogic transactions, and the Michigan Survey of Consumers.

title: Asset Insulators
author: Gabriel Chodorow-Reich, Andra Ghent, Valentin Haddad
context: This paper studies U.S. life insurance companies using detailed NAIC regulatory holdings (2004–2014) and daily TRACE corporate bond prices to estimate how idiosyncratic bond price shocks pass through to insurer equity, with special focus on the 2008–2009 financial crisis (crisis window Jan 2008–Dec 2009). Units of observation include individual insurers (a publicly-traded subsample and the industry universe) and cusip-level bonds. The institutional setting emphasizes insurers’ general-account assets, long-term policy liabilities, state guaranty regimes, and binding capital/market frictions during the crisis.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: Marketing Mutual Funds
author: Nikolai Roussanov, Hongxun Ruan, Yanhao Wei
context: This triplet refers to a model-based counterfactual computed for year 2015 using the paper's estimated structural search-and-learning model (estimated on CRSP and Morningstar data). The experiment sets all active funds' marketing expenses to zero (bj=0) and resolves the equilibrium (funds reoptimize fees; index fund price held fixed). Units are heterogeneous retail investors who sequentially search (with a distribution of search costs); the outcome is the model-implied aggregate search costs across investors in that no-marketing equilibrium.
identification_methods: others

title: Marketing Mutual Funds
author: Nikolai Roussanov, Hongxun Ruan, Yanhao Wei
context: This paper studies the U.S. mutual fund industry using CRSP and Morningstar data on 2,285 diversified domestic equity funds (27,621 fund-year observations) spanning 1964–2015, with many structural estimations focused on 2001–2015. Units are fund-year observations and heterogeneous retail investors who sequentially search. It models fund choices of expense ratios and 12b-1/distribution marketing fees (capped at 1% by the SEC), decreasing returns to scale, and Bayesian learning about unobserved manager skill to quantify how marketing and search frictions shape flows, prices, and welfare.
identification_methods: others

title: Macroprudential FX Regulations: Shifting the Snowbanks of FX Vulnerability?
author: Toni Ahnert, Kristin Forbes, Christian Friedrich, Dennis Reinhardt
context: This paper analyzes the effects of macroprudential foreign-exchange (FX) regulations on bank and corporate FX borrowing across 48 countries (excluding reserve issuers) over 1995–2014. Using a country-quarter panel of policy changes compiled from four sources and BIS measures of cross-border bank loans and international debt issuance, the authors examine how asset- and liability‑side FX measures aimed at banks shift FX exposure between banks, corporates and investors, controlling for country and time fixed effects and macro/global covariates.
identification_methods: other panel regressions

title: Do Fire Sales Create Externalities?
author: Sergey Chernenko, Adi Sunderam
outcome: Aggressive use of cash to accommodate flows
context: This paper studies US open-end domestic equity mutual funds over 1994–2016 using semi‑annual SEC N‑SAR filings linked to CRSP and Thomson Reuters holdings. Units are fund-quarter observations and the stocks they hold; the institutional setting involves mutual‑fund redemption dynamics, fund-level cash buffers, portfolio managers and investment‑adviser affiliations, and portfolio illiquidity. The authors exploit cross‑fund and over‑time variation — including portfolio‑manager assignments to additional funds and investment‑adviser mergers — to assess whether and how funds internalize the price impact of their trading on other funds, and the consequences for cash management, stock volatility, and spillovers.

title: International Yield Curves and Currency Puzzles
author: Mikhail Chernov, Drew D. Creal
context: This paper analyzes monthly U.S. and four foreign government zero-coupon yields and bilateral nominal exchange-rate returns (USD vs EUR/DEM, GBP, JPY, AUD) from January 1983 to April 2019, including pre/post-Global Financial Crisis subsamples. The unit of observation is country-level sovereign bond yields and exchange-rate depreciation rates from the perspective of a U.S. investor valuing domestic and foreign bonds. The institutional setting is developed-country government bond and FX markets under varying macro regimes (including low-rate/ZLB episodes). The authors combine affine term-structure and VAR/state-space estimation to study bond–FX spanning and pricing-kernel components.

title: Partisan Professionals: Evidence from Credit Rating Analysts
author: Elisabeth Kempf, Margarita Tsoutsoura
context: This paper examines U.S. corporate credit-rating analysts and their rating actions from 2000–2018. The authors link 557 analysts (primarily based in New York City and Chicago) to voter-registration party affiliations from Illinois, New Jersey, and New York City and their ratings of 1,984 U.S. firms at Fitch, Moody’s, and S&P. title: Debt Relief and Slow Recovery: A Decade after Lehman
author: Tomasz Piskorski, Amit Seru
context: Using a representative Equifax 10% panel of roughly 13.5 million active U.S. consumers (2007:Q2–2017:Q4) and zip‑/county‑level outcomes, the paper studies household and regional recovery after the Great Recession (post‑Lehman). It compares pre‑(2007–2009) versus post‑intervention (2010–2016) periods across U.S. zip codes to link delinquency, foreclosures, house prices, consumption, and unemployment to spatial exposure to mortgage frictions (ARM share, HARP eligibility, servicer capacity) amid policy responses (QE, HARP, HAMP, near‑zero rates). Units are individual borrowers and zip‑code/county regions in the United States.

title: The Creation and Evolution of Entrepreneurial Public Markets
author: Shai Bernstein, Abhishek Dev, Josh Lerner
outcome: Probability of introducing new second-tier exchange
context: The effect is estimated in a country-year panel (113 countries) covering 1990–2013, where the dependent variable is a binary indicator that a country introduced (and still had active) a new second-tier exchange by the observation year. The key regressor is lagged national patent application volume; regressions include country fixed effects and, in robustness checks, year fixed effects. The paper reports that a one standard-deviation increase in lagged patent filings raises the probability of introducing a second-tier market by about 19–22%.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: On the Direct and Indirect Real Effects of Credit Supply Shocks
author: Laura Alfaro, Manuel García-Santana, Enrique Moral-Benito
context: The paper studies bank lending supply shocks and their propagation through buyer–supplier networks in Spain using administrative firm-level and matched bank–firm loan data (Spanish Credit Registry) for 2003–2013. Units are firms (≈1.8M) and banks (≈235); authors construct year-by-year bank–year supply shocks via matched employer–employee high-dimensional fixed effects and combine firm balance sheets with 2010 input–output tables to measure downstream/upstream exposure. They analyze direct and indirect effects on employment, output and investment across 2003–2007 (expansion), 2008–2009 (financial crisis) and 2010–2013 (recession).

title: Factor Momentum and the Momentum Factor
author: Sina Ehsani, Juhani T. Linnainmaa
context: This paper empirically studies monthly factor and equity returns from mid-1960s through December 2015 (U.S. factors from July 1963; global factors from 1990), using factor and portfolio data from Kenneth French, AQR, and Robert Stambaugh. Units of observation are 20 non-momentum factor portfolios and decile/industry stock portfolios in U.S. and developed equity markets. In the asset-pricing setting (Fama–French five-factor and Carhart models) the authors analyze how autocorrelations in factor returns transmit into cross-sectional stock momentum via portfolio sorts, spanning tests, and return decompositions.

title: Naïve *Buying* Diversification and Narrow Framing by Individual Investors
author: John Gathergood, David Hirshleifer, David Leake, Hiroaki Sakaguchi, Neil Stewart
context: Using transaction-level brokerage data from Barclays Wealth (April 2012–June 2016) in the UK, the paper studies individual investor buy-day behavior. The unit of analysis is investor accounts and buy-day transactions (single- and multiple-stock and ETF purchases); samples include new accounts with full portfolio histories. The institutional setting is a mainstream online brokerage platform (SEDOL-identified UK-listed securities) where investors enter monetary amounts per trade. The paper combines descriptive evidence, cross-sectional regressions and simulations to evaluate Naïve Buying Diversification versus portfolio balancing and its welfare implications.

treatment: Advance information provided by leading industries

title: The Term Structure of Equity Risk Premia
author: Ravi Bansal, Shane Miller, Dongho Song, Amir Yaron
outcome: Term structure slope of dividend risk premia
context: This paper studies traded equity dividend strips (futures) in the U.S., Europe (Eurostoxx), and Japan (Nikkei) over 2004–2017, using longer historical dividend/consumption data for forecasting (U.S. from 1979, Europe/Japan from 1994). Units are fixed-maturity dividend-strip contracts, aggregate dividends and consumption; the analysis contrasts term-structure behavior across business-cycle states (NBER/CEPR/ECRI recession dates) and accounts for market illiquidity (bid–ask spreads). The authors estimate Bayesian VAR forecasts of dividend growth and develop a regime-switching consumption-based asset-pricing model to interpret the results.

title: Can the Market Multiply and Divide? Non-Proportional Thinking in Financial Markets

author: Ross Levine, Chen Lin, Qilin Peng, Wensi Xie

title: Employee Costs of Corporate Bankruptcy
author: John R. Graham, Hyunseob Kim, Si Li, Jiaping Qiu
context: This paper studies U.S. public-firm bankruptcies (primarily Chapter 11) using employer–employee LEHD data (earnings 1985–2008) merged to Compustat and the UCLA-LoPucki BRD, focusing on bankruptcy filings from roughly 1991–2005. The unit of analysis is individual workers matched to firms (about 140 bankrupt firms and ~277,000 affected workers), with attention to local labor-market thickness, firm size, and liquidation versus reorganization. Analyses control for industry×year and county×year shocks to isolate bankruptcy-related effects on worker earnings and implied wage premia for bankruptcy risk.

title: Venture Capital Contracts
author: Michael Ewens, Alexander S. Gorbenko, Arthur Korteweg
context: This paper analyzes U.S. VC-backed first financing rounds (seed/Series A) between 2002–2010 (exit follow-up through March 2018), using about 1,695–2,581 deals for U.S.-headquartered startups (mostly Delaware/California). The unit of observation is the entrepreneur–lead VC first-round match and its contract (convertible preferred equity terms such as investor equity share, participation, pay-to-play, and board seats). The setting is the U.S. venture capital market; the authors model bargaining and endogenous selection via a dynamic search-and-matching equilibrium to assess contract effects on startup outcomes.

title: The Effects of Competition in Consumer Credit Market
author: Stefan Gissler, Rodney Ramcharan, Edison Yu
context: The paper studies U.S. local consumer credit markets around the NCUA’s low‑income credit‑union rule reform and its 2012Q2 notification, using 2008–2015 bank regulatory panels and 2009–2017 Equifax auto‑loan data. Units include credit unions, community banks, non‑bank lenders, banks’ markets defined by 5–10 mile radii, and zip‑code auto‑loan originations. The institutional setting is the NCUA’s relaxation of deposit‑taking restrictions for “low‑income” CUs, which enabled CU expansion into nearby deposit and auto‑lending markets and plausibly exogenous variation in local competition.

title: Why Do Firms Borrow Directly from Nonbanks?
author: Sergey Chernenko, Isil Erel, Robert Prilmeier
context: Using hand-collected SEC-filed loan contracts for U.S. publicly traded middle-market firms (annual revenues $10M–$1B) during 2010–2015, the paper estimates the local causal effect of borrowing from a nonbank lender on loan maturity. title: Implications of Stochastic Transmission Rates for Managing Pandemic Risks
author: Harrison Hong, Neng Wang, Jinqiang Yang

title: The Pass-Through of Uncertainty Shocks to Households

title: The Distributional Effects of Student Loan Forgiveness
author: Sylvain Catherine, Constantine Yannelis
context: This paper uses the 2019 Survey of Consumer Finances to analyze U.S. households (individuals aged 22–60) and their federal student loans, projecting repayment under federal programs (FFEL/DL) and Income-Driven Repayment plans (IBR, PAYE, REPAYE) that tie payments to 10–15% of discretionary income above 150% of the federal poverty line and forgive remaining balances after 20–25 years. title: Owner Incentives and Performance in Healthcare: Private Equity Investment in Nursing Homes
author: Atul Gupta, Sabrina T. Howell, Constantine Yannelis, Abhinav Gupta
context: This paper studies the causal effects of private equity (PE) ownership on U.S. for-profit nursing homes and Medicare short-stay patients using facility-level data (2000–2017) and patient-level Medicare/MDS claims (patient first stays 2005–2016). title: Global Pricing of Carbon-Transition Risk
author: Patrick Bolton, Marcin Kacperczyk
context: This study analyzes firm-level financial and emissions data for 14,468 publicly listed companies in 77 countries over 2005–2018. title: Real and Private-Value Assets
author: William N. Goetzmann, Christophe Spaenjers, Stijn Van Nieuwerburgh
context: This paper synthesizes empirical analyses of real and private-value assets across historical and contemporary settings (long-run samples from the 19th–20th centuries through decades up to 2020), focused primarily on the U.S. but also drawing evidence from the U.K., France, Netherlands, and Singapore. title: The Labor Effects of Judicial Bias in Bankruptcy
author: Aloisio Araujo, Rafael Ferreira, Spyridon Lagaras, Flavio Moraes, Jacopo Ponticelli, Margarita Tsoutsoura
context: This paper analyzes bankruptcy cases filed in the State of São Paulo, Brazil between June 2005 and December 2015, linking court records to administrative RAIS employer–employee data to follow firms and workers up to five years after filing. It exploits the institutional rule of random assignment of cases across local courts within judicial districts and the 2005 bankruptcy-law framework to construct a leave-one-out court-level pro-continuation bias and estimate causal effects on firm survival, employee continuation, mobility, and wages.

title: Flattening the Curve: Pandemic-Induced Revaluation of Urban Real Estate
author: Arpit Gupta, Vrinda Mittal, Jonas Peeters, Stijn Van Nieuwerburgh
context: This paper studies how the COVID-19 pandemic (primarily 2020, comparing Dec 2019–Dec 2020 against pre-2014–2019 averages) reshaped within‑metropolitan housing values across the largest 30 U.S. MSAs. Using ZIP-code–month observations of quality‑adjusted house prices (ZHVI), rents (ZORI), listings, and cellphone-based migration, the authors compare urban core versus suburban ZIPs to assess pandemic-era migration, remote‑work capacity, local lockdowns, and housing supply/regulatory constraints as drivers of bid-rent flattening.

title: The Legal Origins of Financial Development: Evidence from the Shanghai Concessions
author: Ross Levine, Chen Lin, Chicheng Ma, Yuchen Xu
context: This paper studies how transplanting British common law versus French civil law affected financial development across Western concessions in China, focusing on Shanghai (1845–1936) and additional concessions in Tianjin, Hankou, and Guangzhou. Units are concession- and grid-cell-level observations and firms (banks, qianzhuang, stock companies, and stock returns). Key institutional shocks are the 1869 creation of Mixed Courts (strengthening British/French legal jurisdiction) and the 1926–27 rendition returning courts to Chinese authority; authors exploit these temporal and spatial discontinuities to identify causal effects.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions

title: Delayed Creative Destruction: How Uncertainty Shapes Corporate Assets
author: Murillo Campello, Gaurav Kankanhalli, Hyunseob Kim
context: This paper examines how business uncertainty affects capital allocation, asset composition, and productivity in the global commercial shipping industry using near-universal ship- and firm-subsector-quarter data (Clarksons) primarily from 2006–2019. title: Measuring the Welfare Cost of Asymmetric Information in Consumer Credit Markets

title: CLO Performance
author: Larry Cordell, Michael R. Roberts, Michael Schwert
treatment: Higher returns on CLO debt tranches
context: This paper studies U.S. collateralized loan obligations (CLOs) and their tranches using near-comprehensive trustee-level data on 2,131 deals and cash flows from August 1997 to March 2021. Units are CLO deals and individual tranches (equity and rated debt) investing in broadly syndicated and middle-market leveraged loans. The institutional setting includes CLO contractual features (coverage tests, reinvestment, term leverage), regulatory capital incentives for banks and insurers, and two major shocks—the 2008 financial crisis and the Covid-19 downturn—used to contrast pre-crisis (CLO 1.0) and post-crisis (CLO 2.0) vintages.
identification_methods: others

title: Revealing Corruption: Firm and Worker Level Evidence from Brazil
author: Emanuele Colonnelli, Spyridon Lagaras, Jacopo Ponticelli, Mounu Prem, Margarita Tsoutsoura
context: This paper studies how randomized municipal audits by Brazil’s Office of the Comptroller General (CGU) during 2003–2014 affected firms and workers. The CGU ran televised lotteries selecting municipalities for audits of federally funded municipal procurement (covering contracts in the two prior years); auditors publicly listed firms implicated in irregularities. The unit of analysis is firm- and worker-level administrative data (matched RAIS, procurement, BNDES loans, and PIA investment) for firms—mostly outside audited municipalities—exposed by these audits across Brazilian municipalities.
identification_methods: RCT; DiD; event studies; PSM; others

title: Information versus Investment
author: Stephen J. Terry, Toni M. Whited, Anastasia A. Zakolyukina
context: This paper studies U.S. publicly listed firms (Compustat and Audit Analytics) over 1999–2015, using annual firm-level panels of earnings restatements (revenue-recognition and irregularity cases) and measures of intangible investment (SG&A or R&D). It exploits regulatory variation around Sarbanes–Oxley (pre/post) and firm-level restatement episodes to estimate a calibrated dynamic general-equilibrium model in which managers choose real (intangibles) investment versus earnings misreporting, intermediaries extract information rents, and disclosure regulation affects cost of capital, firm value, and aggregate growth.
identification_methods: others

title: Information versus Investment
author: Stephen J. Terry, Toni M. Whited, Anastasia A. Zakolyukina
context: This effect is reported from a counterfactual simulation of the paper’s calibrated dynamic general-equilibrium model: the authors impose an extreme environment with no managerial incentives for either real (intangible) investment or earnings manipulation. In that model (calibrated to U.S. firm data), earnings informativeness rises, the cost of capital falls by 0.14 percentage points, and average firm value rises by 2.4%.

title: Corporate Flexibility in a Time of Crisis
author: John W. Barry, Murillo Campello, John Graham, Yueran Ma
context: This paper studies how financial, workplace (ability to work remotely), and investment flexibility shaped U.S. firms' hiring and capital‑spending decisions during the COVID‑19 shock. It analyzes firm‑level CFO survey responses collected March–December 2020 (and a March 2019 survey for investment flexibility) covering public and private firms across industries and 47 states, and validates findings with Compustat and BLS industry data. The authors contrast COVID‑era effects with the 2008 financial crisis to isolate pandemic‑specific workplace impacts.

title: Presidential Address: Corporate Finance and Reality
author: John Graham
treatment: Past forecast errors and negative shocks
context: Using multi-wave CFO surveys conducted primarily in March 2019 and March 2020 (with comparisons to prior Duke/global CFO surveys dating back to the 1990s), the paper analyzes firm-level corporate finance practices across mostly U.S. (and some international) public and private firms. Unit of observation is the firm/CFO reporting internal forecasts, capital budgeting rules, hurdle rates, leverage, payout, and planning. The institutional backdrop is contemporary corporate governance and capital markets around 2019–2020, including the March 2020 COVID shock and attendant macroeconomic uncertainty.

title: The Demand for Money, Near-Money, and Treasury Bonds
author: Arvind Krishnamurthy, Wenhao Li
context: Analyzes U.S. financial markets from 1934–2016 (with higher-frequency monthly analysis since 1991), using aggregate quarterly/monthly data on bank transaction deposits, shadow-bank short-term debt (KVJ deposits), and Treasury securities held by the non‑bank sector. Units are economy‑wide asset aggregates and market yields; the institutional backdrop includes Fed and Treasury policies (WWII market interventions, the 1951 Accord, Regulation Q, and post‑2008 QE) that shift Treasury supply and money‑market rates. The paper estimates how changes in asset supplies affect liquidity premia and money demand.

title: Financial Inclusion, Economic Development, and Inequality: Evidence from Brazil
author: Julia Fonseca, Adrien Matray
context: The paper evaluates Brazil’s 2004 ‘Banks for All’ (Banco para Todos) program using administrative employer–employee and bank-branch data from 2000–2014. It compares municipalities (minimum comparable areas) without federal government bank branches prior to 2004 (eligible) to control cities with pre-existing public-bank presence. The analysis links bank-branch entry, deposits and lending to firm entry, employment, wages, and wage inequality across Brazilian cities, exploiting ex-ante eligibility, branch expansion, and rich city-by-industry and worker panels.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; others

title: Real Effects of Supplying Safe Private Money
author: Chenzi Xu, He Yang
context: The paper studies how introducing federally regulated “national” bank notes affected local economic development in the United States in the late 19th century (primarily changes from ~1875–1885 and outcomes through 1890, with dynamics to 1900). The unit of analysis is towns/counties (town populations and county-level agricultural and manufacturing outcomes). The institutional setting is the post‑Civil‑War dual banking system after the National Banking Act (1863–64), exploiting population‑based capital‑requirement thresholds for national charters and a derived county-level “monetary market access” measure to capture changes in monetary transaction frictions.
identification_methods: IV; DiD; event studies

title: Aggregate Lapsation Risk
author: Ralph S. J. Koijen, Hae Kang Lee, Stijn Van Nieuwerburgh
context: This paper studies aggregate and heterogeneous lapsation behavior in the U.S. life-insurance industry over 1996–2020, combining firm-year regulatory filings for the 30 largest life insurers with a proprietary policy-level panel of contracts (policies issued c.1998–2016) and county/ZIP-level data. It examines how lapsation co-moves with macro and financial conditions (interest rates, Baa spreads, GDP, employment), with emphasis on the Great Financial Crisis and COVID-19, and on policyholder heterogeneity (age, health, income, term vs whole life) for valuation and pricing implications.

title: The Virtue of Complexity in Return Prediction
author: Bryan T. Kelly, Semyon Malamud, Kangying Zhou
context: The paper analyzes US aggregate equity market return prediction and market-timing using theory plus extensive empirical experiments on monthly market returns (CRSP) spanning 1926–2020. The unit of observation is the single risky asset (market excess return); inputs are 15 standard predictors (Goyal and Welch, 2008) nonlinearly expanded via random features. The setting compares low- to high-complexity (P up to >10,000) ridge and ridgeless regressions with rolling out-of-sample evaluation, including performance around NBER recession dates.

title: Intermediary Balance Sheets and the Treasury Yield Curve
author: Wenxin Du, Benjamin M. Hébert, Wenhao Li
context: This paper studies the U.S. Treasury market across the pre- and post-Global Financial Crisis era through the March 2020 COVID episode (roughly 2000s–2020). It analyzes maturity-specific Treasury yields, OIS swap rates, cross-currency basis (CIP deviations), and primary dealers’ net Treasury positions (FR2004) as market-level time series and maturity buckets. The institutional setting includes post-GFC regulatory shifts (higher balance-sheet costs, SLR), large increases in Treasury issuance, and Fed policy interventions (asset purchases, swap lines). Dealers are treated as balance-sheet-constrained arbitrageurs.
identification_methods: other time-series regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: A Portfolio Approach to Global Imbalances
author: Zhengyang Jiang, Robert J. Richmond, Tony Zhang
treatment: Global private savings and asset issuances
context: Analyzes international portfolio holdings and returns across 35 investor and 33 issuer countries from 2002–2019, focusing on the U.S. net foreign asset (NFA) position, valuation effects, and the post-2010 reversal in U.S. privilege. Units are country-level investor portfolios and issuer assets across three asset classes (short-term debt, long-term debt, equity), including private and central-bank (reserves and QE) holdings. The setting emphasizes global savings gluts, reserve accumulation, quantitative easing and short-term policy rates; bilateral market-to-book ratios and exchange rates are used to decompose flows and valuation impacts.

title: Origins of International Factor Structures
author: Zhengyang Jiang, Robert J. Richmond
context: Analyzes international comovements in exchange rates and consumption for primarily 19 developed countries over 1974–2014 (with robustness including 10 emerging economies). title: Broadband Internet and the Stock Market Investments of Individual Investors
author: Hans K. Hvide, Tom G. Meling, Magne Mogstad, Ola L. Vestad
context: This paper estimates effects of Norway’s broadband expansion (≈2000–2010) on household and individual investor outcomes. author: Todd A. Gormley, Vishal K. Gupta, David A. Matsa, Sandra C. Mortal, Lukai Yang

author: Erica Xuewei Jiang, Gregor Matvos, Tomasz Piskorski, Amit Seru
context: This paper studies how the 2022–2023 U.S. monetary tightening (roughly Q1 2022–Q1 2023 Fed rate increases) affected balance-sheet valuations and run risk across U.S. FDIC‑insured banks. Using bank call‑report data and liquid market indexes, the authors mark-to-market long‑duration real‑estate loans, securities and Treasuries for thousands of banks (including GSIBs) to compute unrealized losses, uninsured‑deposit shares, and stress‑test counterfactuals; the analysis emphasizes deposit franchise, uninsured leverage, and FDIC resolution incentives.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Interest rate increase
Outcome: Bank asset market value

title: Business Group Spillovers
author: S. Lakshmi Naaraayanan, Daniel Wolfenzon
outcome: Stock price reaction to new plant announcements
context: This paper examines how regional prevalence of business groups altered standalone firms’ investment responses to the Golden Quadrilateral (GQ) highway upgrades in India. Using firm-level financial data (Prowess) and a hand-collected loan registry, the authors exploit staggered GQ construction timing (mostly 2000–2006; panel data 1989–2016) across cities/districts to study firms (standalone vs group-affiliated), regional credit outcomes, and bank–firm lending relationships under India’s NHDP/GQ infrastructure program.

title: Are Cryptos Different? Evidence from Retail Trading
author: Shimon Kogan, Igor Makarov, Marina Niessner, Antoinette Schoar
context: Using time-stamped trade and portfolio data from eToro between January 2015 and December 2019, the paper studies roughly 200,000 retail accounts (predominantly European) and daily trading in cryptocurrencies (mainly Bitcoin, Ethereum, Ripple), the top 200 stocks, and gold on the eToro platform (many trades via CFDs). For this triplet the analysis specifically focuses on the subset of investors who traded both cryptocurrencies and stocks (about 64% of the sample), forming cohort-level "representative investor" aggregates and running day-asset panel regressions of log portfolio share changes on contemporaneous and lagged returns.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; DiD; event studies; other cross-sectional regressions

title: The Credit Supply Channel of Monetary Policy Tightening and its Distributional Impacts
author: Joshua Bosshardt, Marco Di Maggio, Ali Kakhbod, Amir Kermani
context: This paper studies how the 2021–2022 U.S. monetary tightening—when the Federal Reserve raised short-term rates and mortgage rates jumped from roughly 3% to about 7%—affected purchase mortgage originations, house prices, and consumption across U.S. metropolitan statistical areas. Using a 5% National Mortgage Database sample (and HMDA), the authors analyze individual first-lien, single-family purchase loans and borrower groups (by race and income), exploiting fixed underwriting DTI thresholds (45%, 50%, 57%) for GSE, FHA, and VA programs to assess credit-supply constraints and regional spillovers.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: The Credit Supply Channel of Monetary Policy Tightening and its Distributional Impacts
author: Joshua Bosshardt, Marco Di Maggio, Ali Kakhbod, Amir Kermani
context: The analysis examines U.S. metropolitan statistical areas (MSAs) over 2021–2022, testing whether the MSA-level "high-DTI share"—the fraction of 2019–2021 purchase originations that would have had counterfactual DTI >50% if originated in 2022—predicts changes in consumption. The outcome is the change from 2021 to 2022 in MSA-level credit and debit card spending (Chetty et al. Economic Tracker). Cross-sectional regressions across MSAs control for prior spending, employment growth, income per capita, and housing supply elasticity to link DTI-driven credit supply constraints to local spending declines.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others

title: The Credit Supply Channel of Monetary Policy Tightening and its Distributional Impacts
author: Joshua Bosshardt, Marco Di Maggio, Ali Kakhbod, Amir Kermani
context: This paper studies how the 2021–2022 U.S. monetary tightening—when the Federal Reserve raised short-term rates and mortgage rates jumped from roughly 3% to about 7%—affected purchase mortgage originations, house prices, and consumption across U.S. metropolitan statistical areas. Using a 5% National Mortgage Database sample (and HMDA), the authors analyze individual first-lien, single-family purchase loans and borrower groups (by race and income), exploiting fixed underwriting DTI thresholds (45%, 50%, 57%) for GSE, FHA, and VA programs to assess credit-supply constraints and regional spillovers.
identification_methods: other panel regressions; other cross-sectional regressions; others
question:
# Role
You are an expert economist.

# Task
Given a context and a treatment–outcome pair, predict the most likely sign of the causal effect.

# Sign Definitions
- '+': The treatment increases the outcome (positive and statistically significant effect).
- '-': The treatment decreases the outcome (negative and statistically significant effect).
- 'None': No statistically significant effect.
- 'mixed': The effect varies across subgroups or specifications.

# Context
This paper studies how the 2021–2022 U.S. monetary tightening—when the Federal Reserve raised short-term rates and mortgage rates jumped from roughly 3% to about 7%—affected purchase mortgage originations, house prices, and consumption across U.S. metropolitan statistical areas. Using a 5% National Mortgage Database sample (and HMDA), the authors analyze individual first-lien, single-family purchase loans and borrower groups (by race and income), exploiting fixed underwriting DTI thresholds (45%, 50%, 57%) for GSE, FHA, and VA programs to assess credit-supply constraints and regional spillovers.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: DTI thresholds binding
Outcome: Mortgage originations

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Managing Mental Accounts: Payment Cards and Consumption Expenditures
author: Michael Gelman, Nikolai Roussanov
context: This study uses monthly proprietary card-transaction data (2010–2013) from Israel to analyze 13,291 retail store members (individuals) who exogenously received a new general-purpose store credit card when their three-year membership expired. A large Israeli retail chain required the new card to receive member discounts; cards were applied for in-store and mailed within 7–10 business days. The setting features staggered expiration timing, limited pre-2018 credit scoring, ubiquitous credit-card payments, and detailed per-card monthly spending, balances, and credit-line records.
identification_methods: DiD; RDD; event studies

title: Regulatory Arbitrage or Random Errors? Implications of Race Prediction Algorithms in Fair Lending Analysis
author: Daniel Greenwald, Sabrina T. Howell, Cangyuan Li, Emmanuel Yimfor
outcome: Measured racial disparities in loan approval rates
context: This paper studies how race-prediction algorithms (BISG) shape fair-lending measurement and lender incentives in U.S. small-business credit markets using Lendio loan application data (2017–2019) and Paycheck Protection Program first-draw loans (Apr 2020–Feb 2021). Units are individual applicants/borrowers and lenders. The authors construct an image-based race measure from LinkedIn photos, benchmark it to self-reported PPP race, estimate how BISG errors bias approval gaps and lender-level loan shares, and simulate counterfactual regulatory shifts from BISG to self-identified race under U.S. fair-lending rules.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

This paper studies how race-prediction algorithms (BISG) shape fair-lending measurement and lender incentives in U.S. small-business credit markets using Lendio loan application data (2017–2019) and Paycheck Protection Program first-draw loans (Apr 2020–Feb 2021). Units are individual applicants/borrowers and lenders. The authors construct an image-based race measure from LinkedIn photos, benchmark it to self-reported PPP race, estimate how BISG errors bias approval gaps and lender-level loan shares, and simulate counterfactual regulatory shifts from BISG to self-identified race under U.S. fair-lending rules.

title: Regulatory Arbitrage or Random Errors? Implications of Race Prediction Algorithms in Fair Lending Analysis
author: Daniel Greenwald, Sabrina T. Howell, Cangyuan Li, Emmanuel Yimfor
outcome: Share of loans to Black borrowers
context: This triplet comes from a simulated counterfactual in which regulators switch from BISG-based evaluations to regulation using self-identified race — operationalized in the paper by using image-based race (from LinkedIn photos) as a proxy for actual race. The exercise uses U.S. small-business lending data (Lendio applications, 2017–2019, and PPP first-draw loans, Apr 2020–Feb 2021) at the applicant/borrower and lender level and finds higher shares of loans to actual Black borrowers but a reallocation toward more affluent, better-educated areas.
identification_methods: other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions; others

title: The Reserve Supply Channel of Unconventional Monetary Policy
author: William F. Diamond, Zhengyang Jiang, Yiming Ma
context: This paper studies how large Federal Reserve reserve injections from QE (primarily 2007–2018, focusing on the 2008–2017 QE episode) affected US commercial banks’ balance sheets and loan supply. Using U.S. bank-branch, county- and state-level data (2001–2017) on deposits, mortgages, syndicated loans, and Call Report balance sheets, the unit of analysis is banks/branches and local markets. The institutional setting is the U.S. banking system during post-crisis QE, exploiting internal capital market reallocation after local natural disasters, Bartik deposit-growth variation, and daily TGA shocks to identify causal effects of reserve supply.
identification_methods: IV; other panel regressions; other time-series regressions; others

title: The Economics of “Buy Now, Pay Later”: A Merchant’s Perspective
author: Tobias Berg, Valentin Burg, Jan Keil, Manju Puri
context: This paper studies the merchant economics of Buy-Now-Pay-Later (BNPL) using microdata from a German e-commerce furniture retailer. It combines an early-2022 randomized controlled trial that randomized display of a pay-in-30 BNPL option at checkout (~75k customers) with 2021 observational data on ~595k BNPL applications (customer credit scores, cart margins, approvals, defaults) and county-level panels (2016–2019) of checkouts to assess default cyclicality. Units include customers, shopping carts/transactions, BNPL applications, and counties; BNPL is offered in-house and subsidized by the merchant.
identification_methods: RCT; IV; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

It combines an early-2022 randomized controlled trial that randomized display of a pay-in-30 BNPL option at checkout (~75k customers) with 2021 observational data on ~595k BNPL applications (customer credit scores, cart margins, approvals, defaults) and county-level panels (2016–2019) of checkouts to assess default cyclicality. Units include customers, shopping carts/transactions, BNPL applications, and counties; BNPL is offered in-house and subsidized by the merchant.

# Treatment–Outcome Pair
Treatment: Making BNPL available to low-creditworthiness customers
Outcome: conversion likelihood

# Output Format
Respond with a JSON object containing:
- predicted_sign: "+", "-", "None", or "mixed"
- reasoning: A concise explanation of your reasoning

title: Financial Inclusion Across the United States
author: Motohiro Yogo, Andrew Whitten, Natalie Cox
treatment: Additional years of access to employer retirement plan
context: Using U.S. administrative tax and information returns (primarily 2006–2019, with 2015–2019 cross-sections), the paper studies retirement- and bank-account participation for the universe of U.S. households with a member aged 50–59 across ZIP Code Tabulation Areas (ZCTAs). It leverages employer-level timing (whether/when firms start retirement plans after a 2010 baseline) and plan features (automatic enrollment), merges Form W-2/1099/5498 with Form 5500 and state auto-IRA mandates, and examines geographic correlates of financial inclusion to evaluate causal effects of access to employer plans.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Financial Inclusion Across the United States
author: Motohiro Yogo, Andrew Whitten, Natalie Cox
treatment: Automatic enrollment in an employer retirement plan
context: Using U.S. administrative tax and information returns for households with a member aged 50–59, the paper estimates the causal effect of employer retirement plan features for workers who lacked access in 2010. It exploits employer timing of starting plans after a 2010 baseline (access measured 2011–2019) and an intent-to-treat IV based on counterfactual access had the worker remained with the 2010 employer. The reported estimate: automatic enrollment raises retirement-account participation by 28 percentage points in the lowest income quintile.
identification_methods: IV; other cross-sectional regressions; other panel regressions

title: Public Goods Under Financial Distress
author: Pawel Janas
context: This paper studies U.S. municipalities during the Great Depression (annual data 1924–1943), focusing on cities (population >1,000 in five states and all cities >100k) and municipal bonds, and on individual local public-sector workers via linked census records. It exploits variation in pre-1929 municipal leverage and in bond maturity schedules amid a setting of minimal federal/state fiscal backstops, widespread banking panics (1930–33), and collapsing municipal credit to identify how debt-driven refinancing constraints affected local public spending, infrastructure investment, crime, health, and workforce composition.
identification_methods: DiD; event studies; other panel regressions
